column10: b'b" Hi there
column11: I\'m not positive this is the same issue
column12: but I can explain one way this can happen. When the animation option is set to \'fade\'
column13: the block of code [beginning at line 451 of the orbit js file]url sets the **current** slide\'s opacity to zero and then animates it back to 1 (as well as setting the z-index value to 3): There are exactly two occurrences of the word \'opacity\' in that file
column14: both in the referenced conditional block. This means that all slides but the current slide _always have their opacity set to 1_.  When I inspect the running slider in Firebug etc
column15: this is exactly what I seea series of slides
column16: all of which have a style attribute containing \'opacity: 1\'. What\'s more
column17: with the \'fade\' animation
column18: all the slides occupy the same area on the screen (i.e. they\'re stacked
column19: one on top of the other). This in turn means that
column20: unless there is a background colour or background image on the slide
column21: or unless the img element occupies the entire area of the slide
column22: other slides _must_ be visible behind the current one. I don\'t have a remotely-accessible version
column23: and I haven\'t yet tried to roll a patch
column24: but I\'d start with something like thisI think it\'ll work because jQuery will start the first animate call
column25: then move on to the next before the first is complete: It\'s likely more efficient to choose the elements to animate to transparency from this.$slides (i.e. instead of doing another collection from scratch); this is just something you might consider testing. Let me know if I can provide further info."'

column15: the slider "works" semi-sort of. The loading animation is still constantly being played through the entire thing as well. I\\\'ll probably just axe the code from the stylesheet and be done with that entirely.  As for the slides... Just before slide A goes away
column16: it\\\'s opacity goes to 0
column17: then comes back

column23: once it\\\'s time for another slide to come
column24: slide A then comes back. Do you think changing the z-index to a negative number to hide behind all page elements would be a workable solution?\''

column10: b"b' This is still happening in v3.0.5'"
b'b" Thanks to ctorgalson\'s start
column11: I figured out how to get this to work using the fade method
column12: even in IE8. First
column13: in your theme\'s CSS
column14: add the following:  .orbit-slide { visibility: hidden; } This hides all slides by default and doesn\'t use the opacity property which isn\'t well supported in IE8. Next in the Orbit js file
column15: around line 214
column16: add the visibility property
column17: as shown below. This sets the first slide to visible on initial load. Finally
column18: around line 485
column19: use the following to fix the animation:.  Hopefully Zurb resolves Orbit to work with transparent slide backgrounds so this fix doesn\'t have to be applied each time."'

column10: b'b\' I came up with an another way to workaround this. Add this line (.siblings().fadeOut();)  at the end of the setupFirstSlide function line 221 in the  file
column11: this will hide all sibling slides underneath the first slide  setupFirstSlide: function () {  //Set initial front photo z-index and fades it in  var self = this;  this.$()  .css({"visibility" : "visible"
column12:
z-index" : 3})  .fadeIn(function() {  //brings in all other slides IF css declares a display: none  self.$({"display":"block"})  }).siblings().fadeOut();;}, Then replace the animation option function on line 632, this will quickly fadeOut all sibling slides and fadeIn the activeslide all slides when triggering the next, prev buttons.  if ( == "fade") {     this.$();    this.$slides    .eq()    .css({"opacity" : 0, "z-index" : 3})    .animate({"opacity" : 1}, , ).fadeIn();;    } If you are using \\\'horizontal-push\\\' option use this code for the function on line around 675  //horizontal-push   if ( == "horizontal-push") {    if (slideDirection == "next") {    this.$slides      .eq()      .css({"left": , "z-index" : 3})      .fadeIn().animate({"left" : 0}, , );    this.$slides      .eq()      .animate({"left" : -}, ).fadeOut();    }    if (slideDirection == "prev") {    this.$slides      .eq()      .css({"left": -, "z-index" : 3})      .fadeIn().animate({"left" : 0}, , );    this.$slides      .eq()      .animate({"left" : }, ).fadeOut();  }    } Hope this helps anyone.-Nolanurl \''
foundation-sites	228	closed	17	crowlatt	2012-01-13 22:44:06	111.23		+1		b'b\' Having experienced the same issue I found the solution for me to be setting in orbit js additional css left : 0px on first slide. setupFirstSlide: function () ... .css({"z-index" : 3,"left":"0px"}) ... Then changing orbit CSS file to: .orbit .orbit-slide { max-width: 100%; position: absolute; top: 0; left:-910px;} -910 being the width of the holding div. Works for me with transparent png\\\'s.\''

b"b' Orbit 1.4.0 opacity problem'"
b'b" When one or more slide images are smaller than the others
column11: then when the smaller image is shown the larger images appear in the background because the smaller image doesn\'t fill up the frame and you\'re using z-index to change the layer order for visibility. So
column12: when you change z-index for images not being displayed I think you should also change opacity for non-displayed images to 0
column13: then set it to 1 when an image IS being displayed. "'

column10: b'b\' Note: This happens using the "fade" transition. \''

b'b" Simply stacking all the slides without hiding the underlaying layers on startup is also a big problem if you use Orbit as a content slider
column11: because if the box doesn\'t have a -image you will see them all the same time."'

Otherwise here is another idea that might be able to remedy this issue:Scan through all slides that are currently in the Orbit slider and determine height of the largest slideAutomatically adjust all slides to have the height of the largest slideIf a background-color or background-image property is NOT being set on each of the slides then automatically apply a user-definable background color by default. If someone wants to take a crack at this and open a PR that would help speed things up. Otherwise expect to see some changes later in the week. Cheers!"'

b"b' Performance: Import Compass Mixins only partially'"
b'b" Hey
column11: stunning work on Foundation 3.0. It\'s become really awesome! I use Foundation in a Rails app doing live reloading on file changes. I noticed a significant load time I was never used to before. Trying to trace the culprit and enabling myself to try more iterations in a shorter amout of time I was able to cut down site reload time from 12.4 seconds to 4.4 seconds by only partially importing the required compass mixins. Is there another way to make compilation even faster? _Edit_: No scientific time measurement done
column12: just measuring it with the stopwatch three times for each version. It feels much more snappy now. Cheers
column13: Thomas"'

column10: b'b" Thanks for looking into this it\'s true the full Compass takes a little more time. We don\'t want to necessarily have the base install for Sass omit parts of Compass
column11: since we\'re not sure what people will try and use
column12: but this is a good FAQ example for anyone who wants to speed up their processing."'

column10: b"b' How about a comment right next to the import pointing people in the right direction?'"
b"b' That would do it. Can I hit you up for the pull request? :)'"
b"b' Could you reopen this so I can reference a new commit?'"
b"b' You know it.'"
b"b' Please feel free to change the wording or place of the note. Thanks for accepting this PR
column11: it should help a lot when people use a development web server that restarts the app every time a change takes place.'"

column11: but the only reason we\'re not using the gem version is we can\'t find a clean way to set the default of modular scale.  Specifically in we set  .  Although this doesn\'t appear to reset the default size.  Any ideas on how to accomplish this? Thanks and great work on modular-scale!"'

column10: b"b' Thanks
column11: yeah hopefully we will nail it down. Mason and I are pretty swamped with other work at the moment. Really want to get this working though.'"

column10: b'b" Yeah
column11: we totally understand! On top of the problem with including it as a in out settings file
column12: we have one other small request :)  We want to include these options as part of our customizer CSS downloader
column13: but since the variable is 2 numbers we\'re having difficulty. Would it not be slightly better to do something like and so that the numbers could be referenced separately? Or does this present complications with all the calculations?"'

column10: b'b" You could construct your $base-size variable using those two variables. It would take a little work to make those configurable variables tho.  I\'m hesitant to limit modular scale that way
column11: since the current architecture allows you to use as many significant numbers as you need. I could see a legit use of three numbers. more would be pretty suspect
column12: but the ability is there. same thing with multiple ratios. I often layer two ratios when I use ms. "'

column10: b'b" Ah
column11: right. I forgot about those features. I haven\'t played with multiples yet. We\'ll keep trying to hack a way to make it work with our CSS customizer!"'

column10: b"b' So the issue is with multiple !default declarations. By passing one var onto another we should be able to make everything work. Chris
column11: if you prefer we can pass those two vars down to a single $base-size declaration so they wont conflict. We can also rename it something a little more accurate for the use case in Foundation: $base-sizes At any rate
column12: this will all be changes to Foundation setup independent of modular scale.'"

b'b\' Thought I\\\'d share something I\\\'m working on that may get at some of what folks are wanting.  I\\\'ve taken the following plugin url  and refactored it to work with multiple instances (eg
column11: call it on multiple elements)
column12: as well as making several other changes: better handling of height calculations for mobile devicesability to hide the element when you get to the  of the parent elementfadeIn effect (instead of slide)and  support via portions of jQuery Mobile (as I also mention here: url  Since I haven\\\'t yet launched this feature someplace public I threw together a JS Bin to give a simplistic example (plus the accompanying code): url If you scroll down in the JS Bin example you should see near the top right corner and near the bottom right corner.  Neither link does anything (they\\\'re just examples).  Also
column13: there\\\'s some weird complications with doing this in JS Bin
column14: so the positioning is a bit funky
column15: but on my test site everything is working properly. So my example illustrates how _I\\\'m_ intending to use this code
column16: but it could be applied in lots of different ways
column17: including what I think folks are asking about here in this thread.  For my purposes I\\\'m not intending to do the full width Nav and Footer that are often desired (nothing wrong with thosejust not what is needed for my current project); instead I\\\'m planning to have a Menu icon in the top-right corner that would call a Foundation Reveal (containing the Menu)
column18: and in the bottom-right a Up arrow icon that will scroll you back to the top of the page.  My plan is that these would only be displayed on mobile devices. So that\\\'s all just explaining why my example uses the particular layout that it does. I think however that this code should work decently well for things such as a Sidebar
column19: Nav
column20: Footer
column21: etc.  Basically you can call the code on any element
column22: and you use a little CSS to handle some of the positioning
column23: but this plugin sidesteps a lot of the fixed positioning headaches that can appear on mobile devices (eg
column24: url  because it works by changing the property of the element.  To be extra clear though
column25: this plugin is not true fixed positioning
column26: and is definitely _not_ the exact same thing as the Affix plugin used in Bootstrap. I think the methods used in this plugin are similar to what jQuery Mobile used once upon a time to get "fixed" elements (I\\\'ve not been able to wrap my brain around how they\\\'re doing things now). So I\\\'m not suggesting this plugin is appropriate for all cases.  But I thought I\\\'d share it for those for whom it might get at what they are wanting. A few final caveats
column27: etc.:I do _not_ have access to lots of mobile devices
column28: so ironically I\\\'ve not been able to test the plugin very much on mobile (which is the context that I\\\'m exclusively planning to use it for).  Limited testing on a few devices (both Android and iOS) have been positive though.  Also
column29: don\\\'t use the JS Bin example for testing this particular plugin; make a test page someplace else as the JS Bin example is only approximating what I\\\'m observing elsewhere (not sure why the weirdness). If I have time perhaps I\\\'ll throw together a better example at some point.If you decide to make use of the plugin I\\\'d appreciate it if you would leave the credits referring to myself (Sean) and the original author (Yair) in the plugin. I\\\'d love to see someone take this code and further improve it (especially Zurb
column30: making this part of Foundation). I\\\'ve had a brief email exchange with the original author about a month or so ago (asking him some questions) and he was very friendly and I would expect he would be fine with others making improvements (since he seemed fine with my doing so).  The code is still rough around the edges
column31: and the improvements have been focused on my particular project
column32: so undoubtedly some things could be improved for more general use.If anyone does make improvements I\\\'d just again ask that you leave the credits in the plugin referring to myself and the original author
column33: and **also** that you share your improvements with the community.  :) I hope you all will find this helpful.  And maybe if the Zurb folks like it enough we\\\'ll see it get added (in some form) to Foundation! Sean\''

column10: b"b' FYI: Modernizr 2.6.2 causes Firefox to jump to page top on Reload'"

b'b" Since Foundation has switched to Modernizr 2.6.2 with Foundation 3.2 I thought it would be helpful to give a heads up that there is a small bug in Modernizr 2.6.2 that causes Firefox to lose its position on the page when you manually Reload the page (ie
column11: F5 key).  Basically this bug is a regression that is caused by a fix for a Safari bug.  It\'s not a huge deal
column12: but it is the kind of thing that folks upgrading to Foundation 3.2 might wonder if was an issue in Foundation (and end up spending a lot of time trying to determine the specific cause). The following is the issue on the Modernizr Issue Tracker and contains the current workaround:url "'

column10: b'b" Thanks @EnigmaSolved! We\'ll keep this up here until they release a new version."'
b"b' @zurbchris: Glad to help!  :)'"

b'b" @zurbchris: It looks like the underlying bug in Firefox has been fixed in more recent versions.  I\'ve tested Modernizr 2.6.2 in Firefox 18.0.1 (Windows 7) on two different computers and everything seems to be fine now.  So I\'ll go ahead and close this issue for now.  If anyone is still seeing this please post and I can reopen it."'

b'b" Looks like this bug is back in Firefox 19.0 (at least on Windows 7 64bit).  Read the Modernizr thread url  for info on the current workaround.  I\'ll close this issue again  the regression in Firefox gets fixed."'

b'b" It looks like this bug isn\'t present in Firefox 23 (tested on Mac OS X 10.8.4 and Windows 7) so I\'m going to close out this issue. Please reopen if you\'re still running into issues @EnigmaSolved
column11: thanks!"'

column10: b'b" @mhayes
column11: Thanks for the followup and yes
column12: I agree that it appears to be fixed.  I\'ll reopen if it shows up again (hopefully there won\'t be any further regressions in Firefox regarding this issue).  :)"'

column10: b'b" Hi all
column11: Having an em-based media query for the top bar was causing issues for a lot of people. We have resolved issues currently by mentioning the exact px value in the CSS. If you  the same in your stylesheets
column12: it should resolve this problem.  In current production version
column13: this is already available. Do let us know if you still face the problem. Note: The same is not updated in _ yet and there\'s a pending PR for the same.  url "'

column10: b'b" I\'m still seeing problems with the top  queries in the current version of Foundation 4.  My understanding is that the CSS media queries calculate the viewport width + scrollbar in modern browsers (correctly so
column11: according to the spec) while the JS used only calculates the viewport width without scrollbar.  This is why you\'re getting the problems once you get within ~15px of the set breakpoint the CSS and JS values don\'t match up. To fix this I changed how the breakpoint is calculated in .  Here\'s the new version starting on line 221 for me:  gets the viewport + scrollbar width in browsers that support it matching the CSS value.  I added the conditional for IE8 support as that browser doesn\'t support innerWidth and actually calculates the viewport without the scrollbar.  Changing the <= to < ensures that the problem doesn\'t still occur precisely at your set breakpoint. If you don\'t need IE8 support you should be able to simply change $(window).width() to  in the original function.  You\'ll also want to change the <= to < as mentioned above.  Hopefully this helps someone else!"'

column10: b"b' $base-font-size does not properly support percentages (other than 100%)'"
b"b' On Foundation 4.0.8
column11: overriding $base-font-size variable in my settings file to a percentage value will not yield the expected results.  The problem is that the css being generated is applying this percentage to the tag as well as the child element
column13: yielding a compounding effect of whatever percentage you set there.  For example
column14: setting base-font-size to 75% to the default font size of 16px will yield an effective font size of 9px (16 \\\\* 0.75 \\\\* 0.75). The correct behavior would have been to just apply this once
column15: yielding an effective font size of 12px (16 \\\\* 0.75). Setting this to 100% or flat pixel values do not expose this bug because 100% has no effect
column16: and pixel values will just overwrite the same value on the child (body) element. From : To fix
column17: I would remove the comma on the css above
column18: or more simply
column19: just apply this solely to
column20: rolling it in with the other styles. This bug relates to url '"

column10: b'b" Is it really not possible to have a base font-size other than 16px without messing up the layout? Please fix this @zurb. **Update:** Okay
column11: I\'ve figured out how to make this work for what I want. But it\'s not entirely obvious
column12: due to the somewhat vague and confusing comments in the settings file. (This is with Foundation 5.1) I\'m looking for a 13px base font-size for all elements
column13: but don\'t want the expanded or shrunken grids that a lot of people are seeing (i.e. should still be equivalent to 1000px
column15: depending on how you adjusted your rem settings). The key is making sure is set **before** any Foundation functions are used (most especially **rem-calc**). This might seem obvious in hindsight
column16: but the wording of the settings comments encourages you to move $rem-base around
column17: and depending on where your type settings are in relation to other settings (or imports)
column18: this could happen. Then
column19: setting (or even just  ) will do the trick to decrease your font-sizing correctly. In my case
column20: this does not require the fixes @seantimm implemented in #2329 (and that haven\'t been merged into master yet).  Now
column21: there will be some other settings that must be manually adjusted. One example is
column22: which is set to in . With the default settings
column23: this causes the accordian nav headers to be the same size as the base body text. However
column24: decreasing the base body text size does not decrease the accordion headers (I\'m not sure if this is a mistake or not; it seems like maybe this setting should just be by default)."'

b'b" It seems that not much thought or effort was put into custom forms. I think the reason is they\'re not meant to be used beyond very simple prototypes. If you only have 2 or 3 items in your drop-down
column11: it works. Or if you don\'t care about the later elements. And if your forms only have 2 or 3 fields
column12: then it doesn\'t matter as much that tabbing to the next fields doesn\'t work. The other issues become less important with a very simple prototype and beautiful design is far more important. It\'s a shame because I don\'t see why Foundation 4 can\'t be used beyond super simple prototypes. The grid systems and rest of the components seem production-ready and the SCSS customizations are valuable long-term."'

column10: b"b' Fix for visibility display bug'"

b'b\' The visibility classes use the property of "inherit" which causes the element they are set on to inherit the display property of the parent element. This causes an issue where an inline element is used within a block element as demonstrated on the following page where a label is used within a paragraph of text: url  ![Screen Shot 2013-04-12 at 3 35 54 PM]url  The property should be set to "initial" rather than "inherit" which gives the element the original display property rather than inheriting it from its parent which may be incorrect. The fix is demonstrated here: ![Screen Shot 2013-04-12 at 3 36 14 PM]url  url  BTW: I didn\\\'t modify any of the table styles in the _ file
column11: the same fix could be applied to them but I haven\\\'t tested it. Thanks!Luke\''

column12: so when I click on a Magellan menu link it can be scrolled but not overlapped by the menu itself  '"

column10: b"b' I can see the offset affects both factors
column11: the distance offset for pinning to the top and also the distance offset for firing the destination arrival event. I am having this issue myself. One interim solution might be to put some top padding of height equal to the menu bar on the destination element
column12: so that the content appears below the menu.. Having said that a destination only offset would be nice.'"

column10: b'b\' I figured this issue using smoothScroll script as mentioned in another post. Tried everything
column11: but didn\\\'t get the Magellan to work as it should by it self. Also there is another issue
column12: because the nav element is with fixed position it can\\\'t be centered on the page
column13: without loosing the responsiveness and fluidness of the site.  The only way I found to resolve this issue is to set an inner-wrap element inside the position-fixed bar. This inner-wrap contain the  list of buttons and it\\\'s width is updated via js to the width of the window.  //JS to update width  navWidth = $("[data-magellan-destination]").width();     $(".inner-wrap").css(\\\'width\\\'
column14: navWidth);     $(window).resize(function() {     tourWidth = $("[data-magellan-destination]").width();     $(".nav-wrap").css(\\\'width\\\'
column15: navWidth);    }); \''

column10: b"b' Is it possible to reopen this? The workaround requires using a third party library.  It would be great to have a destination offset added to the magellan library to handle navigation that overlaps content.'"
b"b' agreed please reopen. This needs a bit of work.An offset would be lovely :+1: Ideally there would be an offset for both the nav and the target.'"
b'b\' Hi
column11: you can fix this issue with the ZeptoScroll plugin by Max Degterev.Use the href menu link attribute to get the target element position then pass the value to the scrollTo() function.Example
column12: HTML: <ul id="nav" data-magellan-expedition=\\\'fixed\\\'>  <li data-magellan-arrival=\\\'fiji\\\'><a>Fiji</a></li>  <li data-magellan-arrival=\\\'bahamas\\\'><a>Bahamas</a></li>  <li data-magellan-arrival=\\\'hawaii\\\'><a>Hawai</a></li></ul> Javascript: $(\\\'.nav a\\\').on(\\\'click\\\'
column13: function(){  var elementID = $(this).attr(\\\'href\\\');  var pos = $(elementID).offset().top 80; // -80 is the offset destination
column14: normally equal to the menubar height   $.scrollTo(pos);  return false;}); Note the zeptoScroll plugin works with both Zepto and jQuery
column15: just add the Zepto and jQuery namespaces: (||) at the end of script.\''

b'b\' Foundation Version 5.3.0 I have 2 issues: 1. The "active" class is not set "early" enough ( the link became active if it was behind the fixed subnav )2. The "ScrollTo" function ( used when a subnav link is clicked ) also stopped to early I still had approx. 20 px to go to the destination. The "destination threshold" setting doesnt work as described in the docs(// pixels from the top of destination for it to be considered active)The javascript also uses the setting for the scrolling so increasing the value also increases the "scrollto" offset on click. My solution isnt pretty but functional and compared to other solutions provided here ( switching to bootstrap) a bit less intrusive :) Issue 1: $(document).foundation({ "magellan-expedition": { destination_threshold: 30} }); Issue 2: I solved this by editing  line 44: var scroll_top = ().top ; changed to: var scroll_top = ().top + 20; ( play around with the value until satisfied)\''

column10: b"b' Foundation 4.1.2: Orbit slider not shown in Reveal window'"
b'b" Hi
column11: I defined a modal window
column12: created with Reveal. The modal window opens after a click on a trigger button. The modal window contains an Orbit slider. This slider is not shown
column13: when the modal window opens. Looking into the page\'s source
column14: I see

b"b' Hi all
column11: Is there a reason is included in when running ? If we remove this from that generator script
column12: we could also generalize the statement in to: It honestly seems like a waste right now -as someone could easily  it if wanted either way (which would be crazy). Thanks!  *Version 4.1.3'"

column10: b'b" We use normalize as a reset for Foundation. Feel free to remove it if you don\'t need it
column11: but most people want it."'

column10: b'b" Think there might have been a bit of confusion it\'s not about removing it entirely
column11: it\'s about removing it from the files that are generated with a new project is created. There\'s no need to copy that file to the directory
column12: since that\'s not something you\'d normally modify anyway -plus it can be referenced via the default Foundation directory in your gems folder. I love normalize
column13: it\'s just about cleaning up the generated files upon project creation. And obviously the other part of this would be to compile with Foundation (just add it in as a partial) so it concatenates with the others files."'

column10: b"b' That makes sense
column11: fbdd5a7c5c679ee7c88e9da37fe99e2910918029 fixes this. It will be part of the next point release. Cheers!'"

b"b' Top-bar with .fixed and .contain-to-grid is broken.'"

b'b\' The last version of Foundation 4 (v 4.1.6) has a defective top-bar when using  classes "fixed" and "contain-to-grid" both at the same time.### Expected result In previous versions (including 3.x) top-bar always took full-browser width. Besides
column11: if you wrap it with a you made the top bar stay fixed as you scroll. Furthermore
column12: if you also wrap it with a -to-grid the content of the top-bar was set to the grid width.### Current behavior Broken. Before it used to work well. Now the bar is shown very thick and top part of the content is hidden behind the top-bar. Also the "fixed" container extends beyond the bar in an invisible way that prevents clicking in any content than comes right after the top bar. Broken.  The bar is fixed
column13: the bar items are contained inside a row width but the bar doesn\\\'t use  full-browser width as it used to do in all previous 3.x and 4.x. versions. Broken. The bar is shown correctly but the top part of the content is hidden behind the bar.\''

column10: b"b' Im not sure I have fixed it in terms of x-y animation but I have fixed it in transparency which looks cool.  Line 313 of _topshould have an opacity and transition added. After this the visibility term can be removed if you like or leave it there and IE8 still sort of works with  after a refresh. .dropdown {  position: absolute;  #{$default-float}: 100%;  top: 0;  opacity:0;  transition:opacity 0.25s linear;*  visibility: visible;  z-index: 99; After that look for visibility:hidden and add opacity:0 and visibility:visible and add opacity:1top-bar-js-breakpoint does not need to be changed You may have to add other -moz and assorted animations as you find them.'"

b"b' I solved this by simply overriding the _display:none;_ with _display:block;_ and instead using _visibility:hidden;_ for the _.dropdown_ element. The _.dropdown_ element displays on parent li element _.hasclick:hover_
column11: so you can use that to append styles to be animated. Below is my sass code: One could easily apply some light transform also.'"

b"b' Improving data-orbit-link to act as custom Orbit navigation'"

b'b" As I\'ve mentioned in the commits I know my code may not be the best but it\'s the idea that counts. So please improve it / rewrite as needed :) The idea here is to improve data-orbit-link so that it keeps up with Orbit slides. A class of \'active\' is added (and removed) from the list of data-orbit-link elements as the slides are changed. This information can then be used to visually highlight the appropriate active link as I did on url  on the Testimonials section. An even nicer visual improvement would be to immediately set the active link to the new slide as soon as it is clicked. Then animate in the new slide. Currently the slide is animated in and the appropriate link is changed after the slide has finished animating. This makes the effect appear a little laggy. However I didn\'t want to complicate the code any more until you have a look at it."'
b"b' +1 Just what i needed! Thanks.'"

column10: b'b\' @driesderoeck  ah i see what\\\'s going on. I looked at your markup for sections and I found that you were missing a couple of things.  YOUR CODE: url  DOCS: url  Set "deep_linking: true;". Remove the callback function.  YOUR CODE: url  DOCS: url  You are missing the equal sign on: a. I would give the sections an identifiable name also
column11: instead of just calling it 1. You are also not setting any of the sections to "active" which means there is not default section that opens on document load. Finally you are missing data-slug="panel1" in the content div. Make sure the data-slug name is the same as the anchor tag.  @carloposo  try enabling deep_linking and follow the steps I mentioned here to fix your problem. Once deep_linking is enabled the anchor tags will push the browser window down to where the anchor tag is set. Let me know if this helps. I\\\'ll close this issue
column12: but feel free to open it if this doesn\\\'t solve your problem. Thanks!\''

column10: b'b\' .show-for-large is between medium (600px) and large (1000px). You could use .show-for-large-up wish will mean 1000px+. Also don\\\'t use a breakingpoint wish name starts with a "x" cause there will be a visibilty class generated called .show-for-xxlarge (1920px+). If you name it something like "super" it will be .show-for-xsuper. It will take the largest breakingpoint name and add a "x" in front of it. Also in the  there should be no "!default"\\\'s. I updated the repo to remove these and also changed the variables to contain "small
column11: medium
column12: large

column10: b"b' topbar resize breakpoint bug and expand persistence '"

b"b' The compare for breakpoint in topbar code is wrong. currently:if (!()) should be:if (()) Also the resize below breakpoint will remove the expanded class from topbar. If you resize back above breakpoint it will not be restored. I wrote a patch to save expanded and restore it. '"
b'b" Hi @ricardo-cantu
column11: I\'ve reviewed the current implementation of the code
column12: and it appears to be correct.  () returns true if the current document width is less than the breakpoint (opposite of the media queries).  So if it\'s not smaller than that
column13: it removes the expanded class.  Also
column14: you\'re correct about losing the expanded state if you resize to a larger size
column15: but I think this is an edge case that we shouldn\'t add code for.  We want the top bar to work well at any size
column16: but we shouldn\'t optimize the behavior (and add extra code) for dragging the window size back and forth. Including @mhayes and @mrsweaters in case they want to weigh in or override me
column17: but I\'m closing this issue for now.  :)"'

b"b' Orbit Preloader causes massive reflows'"
b'b\' The Orbit Preloader will cause massive and expensive updates to the Render-Tree
column11: causing the page to use up more memory
column12: slow down the page
column13: or leave visual artifacting over the page.  The Preloader needs to go into the state "display: hidden" for a single DOM-Level Reflow once Orbit declares it is ready
column14: instead of just sitting in the background constantly spinning
column15: causing tons of smaller reflows
column16: over and over.  Check out Chrome\\\'s "Timeline" utility in Chrome Dev Tools
column17: also optionally check the "Show Paint Rectangles" at the bottom of the options menu for the Timeline utility. \''

column10: b"b' Thanks for pointing this out
column11: the preloader is now set to once the window has finished loading.'"

column10: b'b" You should be using .css(\'display\'
column11: \'none\') because using .hide() keeps it in jQuery\'s data cache instead of doing a one-time DOM-Tree Update. I gave this patch a test and it still causes the same Reflows as before.  Edit: Scratch that
column12: This method is not updating the .preloader class at all
column13: regardless of how you apply the display: none. "'

column10: b"b' Any other ideas?'"
b"b' Ah
column11: Appologies. It appears that my JS was cached on Localhost. I had to completely delete the file and restart the browser to get it to see the new code. There are now far less reflows! Thanks for the quick responses! '"

column10: b"b' No problem @KsaRedFx. So use the approach going forward instead of  ?'"
b'b" Both appear to work now that my cache has cleared
column11: It\'s probably best to just close this issue once again."'

column10: b"b' Adjust flex video sizing'"

b'b" I started digging poking into the flex video styling when I noticed my Vimeo videos had a black bar at the top. Playing around with the webkit inspector I was able remove it by adjusting the padding-bottom value.  To be ensure I wasn\'t going to mess up another player by tweaking the values I put uploaded test videos in 4:3 and 16:9 aspect ratio to YouTube and Vimeo. The videos have a yellow 2-pixel border which would be my guide to make sure I wasn\'t cropping content or leaving a black border. I created a sample page with copies of the players at different sizes to try it out (the markup I used is below). It was apparent that there were problems
column11: this is a screenshot using the styling in the master branch:![screen shot 2013-08-25 at 9 11 53 pm]url  The widescreen
column12: 16:9 ratio (56.25%) player had rows of black pixels at the top from the fractional component
column13: rounding down fixed this. The 4:3 ratio (75%) player ends up with black columns on the sides. I mesured the YouTube player\'s chrome and it\'s only 30 pixels tall. So it seems like it\'d be better to just use the 4:3 ratio (75%) and then just add the chrome height to that.  Here\'s the same players using the variables from this branch: ![screen shot 2013-08-25 at 8 54 17 pm]url  Here\'s the HTML I was testing with that includes larger versions of the players:  "'

column10: b'b" Now that I\'m comparing the screenshots I noticed that the 4:3 YouTube player has minimized its chrome out of the way of the video. In my branch both YouTube players still have the full chrome visible. I\'m not sure what the desired behavior is\\xe2\\x80\\x94personally I\'d prefer minimal chrome\\xe2\\x80\\x94but it seems like both ratios should act the same. My patch might be based on a misunderstand of how the padding and margin interact here
column11: I\'ll wait to hear back from a maintainer."'

column10: b'b" It\'d be great to get any kind of a response from a maintainer..."'

column10: b"b' Hey @tikot. This bug is not hard to replicate for me. I have got this issue constantly with Firefox 31.0 and Foundation 5.4.3. I\\xc2\\xb4ve got no extra styling applied to clearing. Just Foundation styles only and the bug happens every first time i open clearing.I think its not a CSS problem. The negative margin-left and -top applied via JavaScript is just incorrect. For me it seems that the -(() / 2) is calculated too fast. Cause clicking to the next image and back to the first image updates this two values and the image is positioned correctly with bigger values. Maybe the calculations need to be done in a .load() callback or something? I will just try some research next week. But in my opinion this issue needs to be reopened.'"
b'b" Agree with @Baedda
column11: this is still present in 5.4.7 and definitely seems the problem that the top and left margins are calculated too soon
column12: against a 1 x 1px image (resulting in the values). Any window resize triggers a recalculation and fixes the centering. Are we able to swap this calculation out and just rely on a css  centering technique
column13: seeing as Foundation 5 doesn\'t support IE8 anyway? "'

column10: b"b' Fixing bi-directionality (bidi)'"
b'b" The [current implementation of RTL support in Foundation 4]url  is helpful mostly in documents which are uni-directional (bidi). It assumes that a document is LTR and provides the option
column11: in SCSS
column12: to turn the whole document RTL. In order to support bidi
column13: Foundation 4 must not reset directionality in CSS or it must do it in a more clever way. The current implementation resets direction to LTR for all of the following elements in CSS
column14: like so: In sites with mixed directionality (bidi) this unconditional resetting causes mayhem because it overrides the various elements\' attribute. For example
column15: if a element in an otherwise LTR document has a attribute value
column16: the CSS reset will override the element\'s declared direction and it will be rendered LTR. [This W3C article]url  clearly explains that directionality should be implemented in markup (if not in unicode). One such clever way may to use the following snippet instead of the on all of those elements above. It sets directionality by selecting on the attribute\'s value. It starts by setting inherited directionality and ends by setting explicit directionality. In my testing it handled the situation perfectly. Here\'s [the markup I tested it on]url  Of course
column17: this only addresses bidi in elements which are not Foundation specific; the grid
column18: for example. The markup I tested it on is very basic and doesn\'t include various Foundation features."'

column10: b'b" Instead of the better reset snippet I\'ve supplied
column11: we can simply not reset the directionality any more."'

column10: b'b\' Thanks for the feedback!  I\\\'ve reviewed the W3C article you linked as well as throw together a sample pen
column11: and I\\\'m coming to a different conclusion than you have drawn regarding the kind of impact this has on the document
column12: so I\\\'ll need further clarification. Per the document: "The CSS2 recommendation recommends the use of markup for bidi text in HTML. In fact it goes as far as to say that conforming HTML user agents may ignore CSS bidi properties." The [CSS property]url  sets the base text direction of block level elements
column13: but it doesn\\\'t override everything else on the page.  You can see this is the case in [my sample pen]url  that is referencing the  and getting set  . Additionally
column14: the direction property has an initial value of
column15: so even if you remove it from being set
column16: it\\\'s still being set to
column17: anyway.  I really don\\\'t think there\\\'s a problem here.  If you have a specific example that demonstrates otherwise
column18: please let me know
column19: as I want to make sure we get this right
column20: but I\\\'m going to close this issue for now.\''

column10: b'b\' We don\\\'t want default framework CSS to touch directionality because it overrides markup directionality
column11: destroying the rendering of the content. The directionality of elements
column12: whether they be block level or inline
column13: [should be set in **markup** only]url  This is because directionality is a content-level thing. For example
column14: When you have a Hebrew or Arabic paragraph between some English paragraphs you\\\'d want to put on that  . Or it could be a whole and it would be inherited to all children elements. Directionality is a content-level thing. To demonstrate
column15: I\\\'ve added a element to the pen. It has an attribute. Since Foundation overrides directionality in CSS
column16: the rendered direction of this is  . I\\\'ve also added a with to demonstrate that it and it\\\'s children are rendered LTR. So not only in-line elements deserve to be free from CSS direction resets
column17: but block elements as well. "HTML user agents may ignore CSS bidi properties" but they don\\\'t. CSS is overriding the elements\\\' attribute and this is why we shouldn\\\'t reset direction in CSS. As for your last paragraph
column18: The [W3 tutorial says]url  "In HTML the base direction is either set explicitly by the nearest parent element that uses the dir attribute
column19: or
column20: in the absence of such an attribute
column21: the base direction is inherited from the default direction of the document
column23: from a coder\\\'s point of view
column24: if the whole document is RTL
column26: if it is some RTL content in the midst of an otherwise LTR document

column10: b'b\' [The MDN article \\\'direction\\\']url  says "The direction CSS property should be set to match the direction of the text: rtl for Hebrew or Arabic text and ltr for other scripts. This should normally be done as part of the document (e.g.
column11: using the dir attribute in HTML) rather than through direct use of CSS.". It seems wrong in claiming that is the default value of  . I\\\'ve made an edit there under "Values" and marked it as needing technical review. I\\\'m not nearly knowledgeable enough in browser quirks to weigh in on whether we should reset or not. So if we do want a reset
column12: it should be something that resets according to the markup
column13: like this: This selector works in all major browsers.\''

column10: b"b' Please reopen and review pull request #3629.'"
b'b" I\'ve reviewed this further and agree that we should look into this deeper.  If we are going to specify directionality
column11: it should probably be addressed more specifically for each component."'

column10: b'b" Also very interested in this problem because it\'s obviously still open in Foundation 5.."'
b'b" This is a very old issue
column11: but we\'re going to close it for now because we\'re not sure if there\'s a straightforward way to implement this with our current codebase
column12: which determines direction with a Sass variable
column13: not the markup of the page. There would be a lot of cases where you have to double up on classes to reverse the direction of components
column14: like so: Of course
column15: we could add an optional variable that allows you to double-dip like this and make bi-directionality work
column16: but it would be a substantial time investment for us."'

column10: b"b' @Limboistik Apparently this issue was there in 4 as well
column11: just no one reported it until now. Thanks! The problem is that both the default query and the retina query are true on retina displays
column12: and interchange matches the last valid rule
column13: which in this case would be the retina rule. I need to update interchange (or someone can do a pull request) to check retina independent of dimensions.'"

column10: b"b' Short webpages cuts off off-canvas menu'"
b"b' If you have a  webpage
column11: with a particularly small amount on content on it
column12: resulting and will only extend to the bottom of the content.  As a result
column13: the off-canvas menu will also only extend to the bottom of the html content.  If the menu has more content than the page content
column14: then the off canvas menu is cut short and does not extend to the bottom of the browser window. This is what currently happens.  The off-canvas menu is cut short and does not extend to the bottom of the page but only extends as far down as the page content.![screen shot 2013-12-30 at 3 14 13 pm]url  This is what it should do.  The menu should extend down fully to the bottom of the browser window.![screen shot 2013-12-30 at 3 13 54 pm]url  Fortunately this is a pretty simple fix with a few additional css rules.  I will submit a pull request soon for this.'"

column10: b"b' Update  to work with background-image'"
b"b' When a tag(not an image tag) has a data-interchange attribute containing an image path it will set a background-image on element instead of trying to replace the innerHtml.'"

b'b" Hell yes... I was just about to build this myself. @zurb PLEASE accept this pull request.  My only suggestion would be to also check for another attribute.  Here\'s some cases:1. If it\'s an render to the  2. If it\'s a and _is not_ defined or false then it\'s inserted in as HTML3. If it\'s a and _is_ defined then it\'s inserted as a background-image attribute You might say at that point that you should make a class and use media queries to define the image\'s source
column11: but that\'s impossible to do in SASS if you\'re forced to do this using a server-side technology.  Currently I\'m in a Ruby on Rails project and rather than write new SASS code and handle this via class changes
column12: I\'d rather have the more semantically obvious option of seeing it directly in the view
column13: rather than to have to consult stylesheets as well.  Besides
column14: doesn\'t that slightly go against the point of using Interchange in the first place?  I think this pull request is a good start though."'

b"b' Automatically generate visibility classes'"

b"b' Replaces most of the visibility classes with a mixin that simplifies the process of adding or removing breakpoints and their associated visibility classes. Resulting CSS is comprehensive without containing any extraneous or nonsensical classes
column11: and is far less error-prone.'"

column10: b'b\' The visibility classes are all working for me
column11: but I can see why there might be some confusion. The visibility loop omits classes that don\\\'t make sense. For example:**.show-for-small-down** (since small is the smallest breakpoint
column12: down" is irrelevant)**.show-for-xxlarge-up** (since xxlarge is the largest breakpoint, "up" is irrelevant) You get the idea. I was trying to keep the list of classes lean, since there are already so many of them. But it seems like omitting those classes that don\\\'t make sense could be confusing for a user. If, for instance, I\\\'m using **.show-for-medium-down**, and I change it to **.show-for-small-down** without removing the **-down**, then I\\\'m referencing a non-existent class, and that element will always be visible. I\\\'m wondering if this is what you were running into. Something like **.hide-for-xxlarge-up** won\\\'t work, because it\\\'s omitted from the loop. Removing those exceptions will make the visibility loop simpler, but will result in more classes being generated. If this is not the issue that you were seeing, please let me know. As a side note, there are some classes in this version that could also be omitted. For example:**.show-for-small-up** (if small is the smallest breakpoint, then everything is "up
column13: so this class is useless)**.show-for-xxlarge-down** (if xxlarge is the largest breakpoint
column14: then everything is "down"
column15: so this class is useless) These types of classes _are_ currently in this version. And even though they\\\'re not especially useful
column16: it\\\'s perhaps worth leaving them in
column17: to protect against the same kind of situation as described above. Thanks!\''

column10: b'b" I get what you\'re doing
column11: the only issue is we\'re establishing consistent patterns
column12: so even though xxlarge-up seems redundant
column13: it\'s consistent with the other classes. the -down classes are left in for legacy purposes so people migrating from F4 won\'t have to change all their visibility classes
column14: but we don\'t use -down for any of the newer visibility classes like xxlarge. Instead of small-down
column15: medium-down
column16: etc. we use **small-only
column17: and medium-only**. This is consistent with our naming conventions for media queries where for example:The medium-up media size is (min-width: 641px)The medium **-only** media size is (min-width: 641px) and (max-width: 1024px)"'

column10: b'b" Ah
column11: I hadn\'t noticed that **-down** was no longer represented in the documentation. I\'ll remove the exception for classes like **xxlarge-up**
column12: so that will be in the compiled CSS for consistency. In addition to **-down** being deprecated
column13: it looks like the plain **show-for-[size]** classes are missing from the F5 documentation. Is your recommendation that I remove the **-down** classes
column14: as well as these plain **show-for-[size]** classes? Or should they be left in? Please let me know of any other changes you would like."'

column11: I think I\'m finally getting it. I should leave the **-down** classes in for small
column12: medium
column13: and large
column14: but no other breakpoints
column15: right?"'

column15: and very little effort."'

I was juste suggesting a _ variable to dismiss all legacy classes and another one to dismiss x-large and xx-large classes because elsewhere (sorry I don\'t remember where exactly)
column11: they were commented out anyway in a recent commit."'

column10: b'b\' @istrasoft Sorry
column11: my fault
column12: I was only responding to half of your comment. I was saying that it would be nice to have one master list of breakpoints
column13: so you could easily remove what classes you don\\\'t need (like xlarge and xxlarge). I think my confusion comes from there being a few levels to what would be considered legacy:The visibility classes like .**show-for-small** and **.show-for-small-down**The breakpoints and associated classes for the pre-**xlarge** and -**xxlarge** era I\\\'m not as familiar with the history of Foundation to know what makes sense to include or exclude under one blanket "legacy" variable. My feeling is that using a variable to omit the plain and **-down** classes is more valuable (and more tedious to do manually)
column14: while removing **xlarge** and **xxlarge** from the SASS is fairly straightforward.\''

column10: b"b' Magellan Kitchen Sink Never Stops'"
b"b' The kitchen sink magellan example just follows you for the rest of the page. Needs an outer bound for where the last section ends so it can stop.'"

b'b" It would make the most sense to create a boundary element for Magellan. For example something like: The quickest way to implement this would be to hide the magellan-expedition element if it passed the position of a particular boundary element. So let\'s assume we could denote that using the attribute
column11: like so: Then Magellan could simply hide the expedition if it passed this particular boundary. Here\'s some JS that could most likely be used to achieve this effect (note that it hasn\'t been tested yet):  "'

column10: b"b' Has there been any further work to get something like this implemented? What if the boundary was just the last section included in the expedition?  Trying to think of use cases where setting the boundary makes more sense instead of having it taken care of automagically when passing the last bound.'"

b"b' Remove float declaration on collapsed column'"
b"b' When using the grid-column function
column11: the float value is defaulted to true which in turn sets the column float to the deafult-float direction. This behaviour is not desired when defining a collapsed column
column12: we just want the padding to be removed. This patch adds the argument $float:false to the grid-column function when defining collapsed columns. Should fix #4329.'"

column10: b"b' Limit legacy visibility classes to legacy breakpoints'"
b"b' When enabled
column11: generating legacy visibility classes only uses small
column12: medium
column13: and large breakpoints. Since those were the only breakpoints that existed in Foundation 4
column14: there is no need to generate visibility classes for any breakpoints beyond those three. This addresses what I believe was an incomplete merge of #4345
column15: where an older version of _ was used.'"

column10: b'b" Ironically
column11: now that we\'ve released the superfluous visibility classes
column12: we can\'t pull them out since that would be a breaking change."'

column10: b"b' @thedeerchild I respectfully ask that you reconsider.The additional classes have not been publicly available for very long
column11: and do not appear anywhere in the documentation.Their inclusion was a mistake.I pointed out the mistake immediately after it was merged: url Unless the developer knows to disable **$include-legacy-visibility-classes**
column12: the extra classes are unnecessary bloat.Including these classes goes against the mobile-first philosophy of Foundation.'"

b'b" This is pretty frustrating.. I HIGHLY prefer Foundation over other frameworks
column11: but when this issue remains unresolved while other frameworks have solid workable solutions for dropdowns
column12: popovers or whatever we prefer to call them.. it puts developers in a tough place. We have to have a solution that works. I\'ve spent hours even trying to utilize jQuery UI\'s collision detection since we\'re already using jQuery UI
column13: .. but haven\'t had any luck so far..  It seems
column14: that maybe stepping back and rebuilding the dropdowns to do all they\'re supposed to be might be a better solution than trying to get this component to do something it was obviously not originally meant to do. Just a thought..  Really appreciate the foundation team and all you guys do.. and hope you can find a solid
column15: reliable solution for the dropdowns.. I really
column16: really don\'t want to have to move to another framework because a client can\'t live with the current ones!"'

column10: b'b" We appreciate your frustration

column12: Dropdowns
column13: Reveal Modals
column14: and others
column15: so it\'s definitely something we\'re working on. Not only that
column16: there will be an accessible collision detection method within Foundation 6 so you check other elements as well.  Until then
column17: we hear you
column18: and we\'re trying to make it better. Chris"'

column10: b"b' 5.2 Sticky top bar delayed on touch device'"
b'b\' On all IOS devices
column11: the body class "f-topbar-fixed" is delayed. The class is added after your finger is lifted off of the screen. This causes the top-bar to not be sticky while scrolling
column12: until the user stops touching the display. Please consider adding touchstart events to the sticky top bar.url \''

column10: b"b' Any movement on this? The sticky topbar is super buggy in IOS7
column11: and worse in IOS6.'"

column10: b"b' FYI @greendezine solved my problem specifically in iOS6.1+ by using CSS: Ref: url '"
b'b" Sticky isn\'t really ideal for Foundation as the browser support just isn\'t there yet. Glad it\'s working out for you here though. As for the touch start event
column11: it would be ideal if the sticky bar was always positioned at the top of the page on start
column12: but for many use cases the bar is somewhere else on the page till the user scrolls past it
column13: touchstart wouldn\'t help as iPhones don\'t register page scroll position till after a  pause in scrolling.  I\'m going to close this for now
column14: as it appears to be a browser limitation rather than a Foundation issue
column15: however if i\'m mistaken please feel free to reopen and elaborate on your solution.  Thankyousomuch
column16: Brandon"'

column10: b"b' Important to note that my work-around using position sticky was not robust when used in conjunction with grid (even on safari ios7+). table-cell display type was not supported very well by position:sticky. '"

column10: b'b\' I know that Foundation and Bootstrap are different beasts
column11: and while I\\\'m sure some will say
column12:
just go with Bootstrap then since they have a SASS port), I think there\\\'s some small  that Foundation could get some inspiration from Bootstrap:[More table styles]url  Right now Bootstrap has more complete styles for admin tools (as a general comment)[Better styled dropdowns]url  current implementation seems a bit clunky.[Affix]url More uniform spacing throughout. Feels like there are a lot of irregular spacing patterns in different Foundation components. [Buttons]url  seem to have a different padding "scale" than [pagination]url I\\\'m going to +1 using @extend as a few others have mentioned. Personally, I don\\\'t understand why  Zurb would go with a library that doesn\\\'t support all that SASS itself does. I get that it\\\'s faster, but @extend is such a handy feature -and to have all consideration of it removed from Foundation because of speed improvements seems a bit silly to me. It\\\'s a port -and an incomplete one at that.  I\\\'m more than happy to create a PR for tables, some style updates for dropdowns and general spacing adjustments, but want to gauge the communities interest in bringing over those. Thanks!\''

column10: b'b\' @HashanP fairly important point about why NPM may not be best. Where do non JavaScript plugins go? If I maintain a django plugin or a php module or anything other than JavaScript... Then NPM is a rather inappropriate place to store it. The nice upside of a new plugin listing is that it isn\\\'t necessarily tied to JavaScript which is why I suggested a tool like DjangoPackages
column11: it doesn\\\'t mandate a particular package management tool chain and can act as a purely unificating force (users thinking "if it\\\'s for foundation it belongs in the index") as opposed to creating any more chances for valuable foundation resources to remain hidden (users thinking "well my plugin isn\\\'t JavaScript so I\\\'m not going to package it for NPM
column12: I\\\'m sure if anyone wants it they can find it"). One other advantage of DjangoPackages is I don\\\'t have to be the maintainer to edit metadata or add a package I just found on GitHub
column13: it makes the discovery
column14: curation and new content on boarding process easier
column15: leaving package management to the package owners discretion.  \''

column10: b'b" ## Regarding web components and Modular JS @chrisjlee Being familiar w/ web components (natively and through web component libraries such as Polymer)
column11: and ES6 modules\\xe2\\x80\\x94as well as tools such as browserify to make modular JS architectures a _lot_ easier to realize\\xe2\\x80\\x94such things are being worked on for Foundation for Apps.  As you may be aware
column12: future versions of Angular
column13: Ember
column14: and other popular frameworks will be re-engineered to work better with Web components and ES6\\xe2\\x80\\x94particularly accessing and leveraging the power of observers
column15: the Shadow DOM
column16: the element and its and properties;  ES6 proxies
column17: and other exciting features.  Accordingly
column18: these things should allow Foundation for Apps to be  more framework-agnostic than when it was originally announced.  When it comes to module JS
column19: not much work has been done towards a particular architecture for the JS associated with Foundation for Apps yet (as far as I know). That said
column20: it has to be done in a modular way to meet the goals of the project I\'d imagine
column21: and the end users of the framework to make apps\\xe2\\x80\\x94developing JavaScript applications in a modular way is a common best practice by modern intermediate to advanced web developers today. ## Regarding the Dialog element @HashanP I myself have voiced support for the dialog element.  Towards the efforts of _Foundation for Sites_ being more accessible
column22: there are in fact plans to finally implement support for the tag.  Chrome 37 and only the recent versions version of Firefox have native support for it as far as I know
column23: but the polyfill is decent enough for it to be supported now
column25: there\'s no reason for _Foundation for Apps_ to not have support for it. Reveal without the use of dialog is currently being planned to be compliant with WCAG standards
column26: and it\'s not decided whether or not support for dialog will be implemented during the final stages of such changes or afterwards.  Being familiar with the basics of using
column27: considering the JS changes needed to be made (for example
column28: reveal shouldn\'t allow other elements to be focusable when active except the address bar via esc)
column29: it\'s undecided whether support for it will be shipped within the next release or soon after the release that\'ll address accessibility woes of Foundation.  It may very well be an implementation separate from the core version of Reveal to be shipped faster.  ## Regarding Dependencies @istrasoft With a modular design
column30: such things shouldn\'t be a problem. Given the fact evergreen browsers are only supported with Foundation for Apps
column31: a lot of weight that was often added to Foundation for Sites to support older browsers not ideal accounting for during the prototyping stage of a web application will be dropped."'

column10: b'b" @rvinay88 If you mean _defining_ functions within the file versus just importing them
column11: that\'s not likely to change. We can\'t anticipate if a function will ever be used on multiple components or not
column12: so we keep them in a separate file. In Foundation 6 our Sass utilities will be a lot more organized
column13: and also separated into multiple files (e.g.
column14: units
column15: maps
column16: colors). It\'s also better for version control if we keep these things in separate files
column17: which is another reason we\'re moving away from one big functions file. The components themselves establish dependencies through imports. So right now imports
column18: which imports  . If any component in Foundation 5 isn\'t properly importing its dependencies
column19: then that\'s a bug and we can fix it."'

column10: b'b" It seems there are two issues here. First is that the browser (Chrome and Firefox tested) will scroll the page up if the bottom of the content is reached. So if your window is 900 px height and your content on one tab is 1300px
column11: you scroll down to the bottom
column12: then click a tab with only 800 px content
column13: the window y position will scroll up to the top to show all 800 of the 900px.  This is likely the desired behavior in most situations.  To avoid it
column14: there must be enough content to go beyond the height of the window on all tabs. The second issue seems to happen in Chrome
column15: but not Firefox.   Even when there is enough content to fill the window height
column16: Chrome will scroll to the top of the page when clicking any tab.  There is a note in the  file that seems related to this issue: When set the other way (the default it seems): Chrome will move the y position so that the hash for the content of the tab clicked is at the top of the window as far as it can go without running out of content at the bottom. Neither behavior is desirable with a horizontal row of tabs that a user may be clicking through because those tab links jump around after each click. The ideal behavior would be for the scroll to happen when deep linking to a hash anchor only if it was called from an element that _was not_ in the dd set of tabs.  For example
column17: in the case of going back to a previous page where a deep tab was open
column18: the window should scroll to the y position it was open at.  If a link somewhere else on the page calls to a deep link in the tabs
column19: it would be appropriate to scroll to that tab.  But when linking from the parent set of the tab
column20: no scroll should happen at all. This can be duplicated by reducing the height of a browser window and using the link from @fuzendesign in firefox and chrome to demo the different behaviors.  I\'m working on this issue at the moment.  But it\'s a bit beyond my skill level. So hopefully by writing it out here. Someone else might get a better grasp on the issue."'

column10: b'b" @fuzendesign I\'d like to apologize personally for the increase in regressions over the last few releases. Around the time of we re-organized some of the teams at ZURB. What this means is that Foundation has more people working on it full-time
column11: however
column12: some of the developers aren\'t as familiar with the JavaScript codebase. Because of this
column13: we\'ll occasionally break something while fixing another issue. We can\'t solve every issue in GitHub for every release
column14: but we do try to prioritize the ones that affect the most people or have the most cascading effects for other components. This one seems to have escaped the giant magnifying glass so far
column15: but I\'m tagging it for the next patch release and I\'ll personally take a look at it."'

b"b' Adding more list variables for flexibility'"
b"b' Hi there
column11: love Foundation! First time pull request here.  I love that you have style for font option for general and now style for tag
column12: and was using them
column13: but encountered an issue where list items inherited and not  . This change will add flexibility by either keeping the current setup or overriding it. Thanks for your consideration.'"

column10: b"b' I too would like see this merged.  Consistency :+1:'"
b'b" I completely understand the ability to customize these values; which is great
column11: but to me this just seems like extra bloat (for the final compilation). Shouldn\'t we be comparing these types of variables to things like and instead of continuing to re-write styles that aren\'t needed; they\'d just fall up the tree and inherit from the defaults. I\'m not seeing dictate anything here that would force us to re-instantiate these values
column12: so why output them? This isn\'t necessarily about this PR specifically
column13: but something to think about for the entire framework. Take the following for example: This is in essence what we currently have going on; why though? Here\'s what I\'m thinking would make sense: Checking to see if the values are different before actually writing them out. Smaller CSS files is really the end-goal here. Thanks."'

column10: b'b" I get what you\'re saying @zslabs but this approach of relying on styles falling up the tree can make it hard to develop and test individual pieces in isolation. Plus I\'m not really seeing the issue with larger CSS files; a more flexible configuration seems like a greater benefit. Production CSS should be getting compressed and gzipped anyway
column11: no?"'

column10: b'b" Of course it gets minified
column11: wasn\'t saying it doesn\'t. Was simply stating that could be a potential area that could be optimized
column12: but do see isolation benefits guess it more depends on not introducing a level of complexity that makes the framework less usable. I\'m almost thinking of what this would do in the same methodology as grunt-uncss does for overall styles; but at a much more granular level within the framework itself.Zach Schnackel"'

column10: b'b" For this specific PR
column11: it changes variables for lists to be more specific.  Using paragraph styling inside of lists makes no sense and is super inconsistent. @zslabs I\'m all in favor of doing this within the framework itself.  Something like grunt-uncss is neat as a concept
column12: but probably not something I\'d ship with a production quality framework."'

column10: b'b" Hi
column11: @zslabs
column12: I see your point. But the reason for this PR was that I did not expect  \'s to change font when I changed I only expected the to change -but by doing so
column13: it overridden element\'s font-family (which is already in output css
column14: so this PR will not change the total numbers of lines in the output). Another way to do it is do this outside of framework
column15: but since options are already available
column16: I wanted to use the feature without the unexpected side-effect. It seems that list styles are the only thing that are effected by paragraph changes in foundation. Thanks for your consideration."'

column18: was there a specific  you were able to debug on a device
column19: to conclusively say that it was the \\\'webkit-backface-visibility\\\' properties? The only sort of diagnostic I can get out of the phone logs is a LowMemory warning. After doing some searching
column20: particularly this post: url  Many think that "-webkit-transition" often causes mobile webkit browsers to crash. Anyone else experience something to this effect?\''

column10: b"b' Compass with Foundation 5.2.3'"

b"b' The update to Foundation 5.2.3 from 5.2.2 is now throwing errors from compass due to the addition of an mixin aturl which is the same mixin as compass url  Removing the mixin from _ lets compass compile successfully Is Foundation 5.2.3+ not going to be compatible with using compass?  '"
b"b' I have the same problem under Foundation 5.2.1.Importing compass after foundation seems work
column11: but obviously is a rather unstable workaround.'"

column10: b'b" This is my fault. I added the mixin when I included autoprefixer. As part of that process
column11: I removed all explicitly vendor pre-fixed properties and re-purposed the existing flag. My changes were subsequently included in a minor release
column12: but then removed again and tabled for inclusion in **5.3**. The mixin isn\'t currently being used anywhere in or
column13: so it could easily be removed. @thedeerchild do you have any thoughts on this? Shall I submit a PR that renames the mixin
column14: or simply removes it altogether? It doesn\'t look like is being used anywhere anymore either."'

column10: b'b" Perhaps prefixing the foundation specific mixins with like f_ or something would be good so conflicts like this don\'t occur anywhere. Basically we need namespaces for mixins!"'

b'b" I\'ve had the same issue causing lots of test failures. I\'ve been able to work around this for now by removing the experimental mixin from _ but it would be nice to have a more permanent solution."'

b'b" Hello all I have totaly drop the prefix in all my projects. According to me it\'s not a problem that a framework should solve but its a job for another tool.Simply use this solution url  @chrispelzer feel free to close this issue if this problem is solved :)"'
b'b\' That is one solution
column11: you are saying to replace compass mixins and let autoprefixer handle the prefixes
column12: correct? I wouldn\\\'t mind eventually switching
column13: but for a version change from 5.2.2 to 5.2.3. I wouldn\\\'t expect I would have to do that. Even if I was to close it out
column14: I would need to open a new ticket to have them remove the "Using Foundation with Compass" at url \''

column10: b'b" Hi
column11: @flexbox and @chrispelzer : ## Regarding Autoprefixer Being a long-time Autoprefixer user myself (I personally use it in _all_ my projects; I also haven\'t had the need to use prefixes in an actual project for almost two years because of Autoprefixer)
column12: it was decided _not_ to include Autoprefixer for Foundation for Sites until another _major_ release after a lot of Foundation for Site users contacted us about being unable to use it for whatever reason with their setup.  Foundation for Apps will include Autoprexier
column13: but we haven\'t decided on a specific date when we\'ll release another major release of Foundation for Sites that\'ll allow us to include Autoprefixer for Foundation for Sites without alienating a lot of users.  Given the fact Andrey Sitnik (the creator of Autoprefixer) and other contributors of the project have made it _very_ easy to use it in a variety of ways
column14: it shouldn\'t be too hard to include it manually with your project for now.  ## Regarding Compass Compass is _much_ more than prefixes. If you _only_ use Compass for its mixins dealing with prefixes
column15: you can definitely remove itbut that\'s unlikely if you\'re making the most out of what Compass offers people who include it with their projects.  Compass allows you to easily create and share extensions and frameworks
column16: and so much more.  I don\'t think it makes a lot of sense to issue a ticket to remove a ticket to remove Compass solely because of prefixes. Given the fact all popular task runners such as _Gulp_ and _Grunt_ have well documented and well designed modules to use Compass within them
column17: I think more reasons are needed from the community for us to remove Compass. "'

column10: b'b" @lozandier
column11: I think you misinterpreted my last comment to @flexbox and this ticket. The Compass mixin **experimental** conflicts with the Foundation mixin **experimental** that was added to Foundation 5.2.3 I thought at url  @tmugford that this was an issue. Unless I\'m reading your comment wrong
column12: then close out the ticket
column13: and I\'ll lock my version to 5.2.2 till I can get around to updating to remove my Compass mixins."'

column10: b"b' I locked the foundation version of my project at 5.2.2 too. If you say Foundation is compatible with compass url  why you have added this mixin?'"

b'b" Horrified to realize I\'m the one who created the \'ll try and get this fixed today. The experimental mixin showed up while we were experimenting with Autoprefixer and shouldn\'t have made it into the release."'
b"b' Fixed in 3b3c67d.'"

column10: b"b' Allow elements with custom validators to still validate against standard validation'"
b'b" Now you can set up an element like this: and have it run the custom validator while ALSO checking if it\'s a valid email address
column11: rather than needing to re-implement email validation internal to your custom validator. I think that if you are going to use html5 input types
column12: you don\'t want the validation to go away just because you are implementing a custom validator. I had to modify one test to support the fact that form submissions would trigger all custom validators
column13: so the number of errors was 3 instead of 1. Could possibly include the following (:191) to make the errors less chatty:  "'

column10: b'b\' @jeaniec  Sorry
column11: this is not completely fixed (even with correcting the typo). The other events (opened
column12: close
column13: closed) are still firing more than once. And the fix as presented seems like a  without addressing the real problem. The real problem is calling .trigger() without the "namespace" and then calling it again with the namespace. Can we simply get rid of the non-namespaced call to .trigger() ? Or does it need to exist for legacy reasons? \''

column10: b'b" Hey @nicholashead
column11: sorry for the premature commit. When I tested the fix on my local machine
column12: I wasn\'t getting double events but maybe I wasn\'t exactly duplicating the problem at hand. I\'m going to put a pin in this and put it on our trello board url  to engineer a better namespacing system. Because it seems that a lot of our recurring issues have to do with conflicting namespace events and it appears there is a mishmosh of using the trigger method as well.  In the mean time
column13: if you want to submit a pull request with a temporary solution that better integrates @andrejpavlovic\'s fix

column10: b'b\' Sorry there\\\'s not a lot to say @rafibomb. Having a quick look through the source shows that someone went to a lot of trouble to _avoid_ having plugins work on dynamic content. url  I mean
column11: I guess that\\\'s a nice way to be able to say "just run $ and we\\\'ll be as judicious as possible with our startup"
column12: but I don\\\'t think that kind of user is really going to be min-maxing their load time anyways. Modules are great
column13: but make it explicitly controllable or don\\\'t do it at all
column14: because at first glance it looks to me as though the tooltips run on a single delegated event handler. If they weren\\\'t being hamstrung by the init process they\\\'d work just fine as is.\''

column10: b"b' @Sinetheta I have no doubt this code was not built with this use case in mind. Having said that
column11: we are working on the next version and the JS will be re-written. Dynamically loaded content will be kept in mind as they are built out. And thanks for the explanation.'"

b'b" @tedivm one year has passed since your first comment to this issue and how much have you contributed to this framework? Nothing
column11: not even forked! Open source doesn\'t mean you get everything you ask for without doing anything. So instead of complaining you could have used the time to create a PR solving the issue or help with the one in talk.  @steoo same to you: your fist comment to this issue was more than 3 years ago and you haven\'t contributed anything yet and not even forked this repo either! Means in the end you need to write code yourself anyway (just not for Foundation) or are dependent on another project again what will only work as long as there are enough developers taking care of all unpaid requests.  back 2 topic:  I\'ve just gone through the whole issue and think there are two problems: 1. changing the of an existing tooltip doesn\'t work (sth as or is missing) \\xe2\\x80\\x93 possible fix in url  2. adding a new tooltip to DOM always requires to initialize it (either via or via  ) and can\'t work as expected by @johnraz The latter can not be fixed because it\'s caused by the architecture of Foundation. Each tooltip is an individual plugin instance and therefore has to get initialized. Just adding a new tooltip elem without taking care of it doesn\'t work by design.  Maybe something we might consider for Foundation v7 @ncoden ?"'
