column11: but once he tried to shut this conversation down I pointed out that the issue was still valid.  On top of that though I actually did go ahead and open a new issue (#10898)
column12: which resulted in this PR (#10957)
column13: which in turn has been completely ignoreddespite people tagging @DanielRuf.  So I totally get that open source software (of which I\\\'ve written a lot) depends on contributions
column14: but if you want contributions you\\\'ve got to be an open community and you\\\'ve got to actually manage those PRs. Making snarky comments and shutting down threads while the issues are still relevant is not very inviting. Ignoring requests for feedback on open PRs
column15: and then ignoring that PR for almost a year
column16: is not going to encourage people to make more PRs. No one is going to contribute when the gatekeepers for the project ignore those contributions.  Honestly though I\\\'ve already moved away from Foundation
column17: and with the responses coming from the "collaborators" on the project I am extremely grateful that I did.\''

column10: b'b" If you\'re not using Sass
column11: you need to use the Foundation download customizer in order to get the RTL version. _After_ you download that custom version then you will add the attribute to your tag to activate it. **You can find the Foundation download customizer here**:url  On that page
column12: Select right to left under the Text Direction heading.![screen shot 2014-08-20 at 3 23 56 pm]url "'

b"b' The keeps the focus as it seems.'"

b"b' But removing the focus is not good for a11y and blind users and other users of screen readers and other solutions. The behavior like this is intended in Chrome and other browsers as far as I know  Edge has an a11y score of 100/100. The behavior is the same.'"
b"b' See url '"
b"b' Would label this with  '"
b'b\' Note: Since we started working on Foundation 7
column11: we (sadly) stopped support
column12: bug fix or new feature for v5. But v6 has the same behavior so I\\\'ll try to reply.  For accessibility reasons
column13: every interactive element (controls
column14: inputs) must have a special look when it is focused. Most often
column15: this is the "blue shadow" the browser shows by default ( ). In Foundation
column16: we remove it (because lot of people find it ugly) but apply a background in return
column17: to keep the button "showing" when it is focus.  We currently use to display the outline only when a keyboard is used on almost all elements (including the button). We could do the same for the button background. However
column18: I am not sure that everyone expect a button to not display any "focus" when a mouse is used.  What do you think @colin-marshall ?\''

column10: b"b' @ncoden just want to make sure I understand your question. Are you suggesting that whenever a button is focused
column11: the background does not change
column12: regardless of it was focused from keyboard or mouse? So that would mean the only visible indicator you would have that a button is focused
column13: is the blue outline if you used the keyboard to select it?'"

column10: b"b' @colin-marshall Exact.'"
b'b"  This is a good question
column11: that I don\'t really have an answer to. @Owlbertz is knowledgable in accessibility
column12: he is probably a better person to ask."'

column10: b"b' The WCAG require the following: They do neither explicitly require an outline
column11: nor a focus indicator when using a mouse. Thus
column12: as most people (mostly those doing design) do not want this little outline we use to hide it for mouse-users for some features. As mentioned in another issue (I am not able to find unfortunately) I suggested that we add a fully customizable focus indication. For the upcoming version.  However having the button color staying the same **for mouse-users** when focused seems ok according to what I cited above.'"

column10: b"b'  Definitely a good idea. Right
column11: or we combine focus with hover if we need another indicator.'"

column10: b"b' @Owlbertz what would be your decision on this? Do we have to change something to improve the accessability and the UX here?'"
b"b' As mentioned above
column11: regarding accessibility the only important requirement is that the focus is visible when navigating with the keyboard.'"

column10: b'b" You can\'t put in _text_
column11: you must use an icon. It looks weird otherwise. If this is not supposed to happen then I will look into if my coworkers royally fucked up the CSS in our app or something (which isn\'t too out of the question either)."'

column10: b'b" Nope
column11: I was able to recreate this behavior. The dropdown arrow is placed using a pseudo-element with
column12: so putting text in there just aligns it to the top. If what you need is a split button where they\'re both text
column13: I\'d recommend using a button group. From a functionality standpoint
column14: they\'re more or less the same. Actually
column15: the button group works more sensibly because it\'s two separate buttons. With the split button
column16: the inside the just prevents click events on it from bubbling up
column17: allowing you to have two links within one anchor."'

column10: b'b" I think there are some styling differences such as hovering over the button highlights the entire row
column11: but yes I ended up opting for a button group. I don\'t actually think having both a split button AND a button group is good design though. Bootstrap doesn\'t do this
column12: and the use-case the code is covering is sort of odd (and highly specific to event bubbling?) What I was actually trying to do in the first place was create some sort of number badge on the button similar to the buttons at the top of this page which show fork and star counts. I think fundamentally a better issue that pertains to that is why do we not have badges?"'

column10: b'b\' We agree
column11: and like I said we already merged the two components for Foundation 6
column12: but we don\\\'t plan on deprecating any existing Foundation 5 components. We also added a badge for Foundation 6! Foundation for Apps [also currently has a badge]url  if you want code for one
column13: although they\\\'re pretty easy to make. It kinda sucks that with features like this we have to say "Wait until Foundation 6!"
column14: but with version 5 our focus is on keeping it stable
column15: which means not introducing any new features or making big changes this late in the game.\''

column10: b'b" Btw after trying to hack the crap out of split button it\'s been made apparent that we\'re using which seems completely unnecessary vs something like inline-block or flex or floats. I think we should drop the use of absolute positioning for something like this."'
b'b" Agreed
column11: the way it was originally designed was fairly narrow\\xe2\\x80\\x94it\'s basically just to make those arrows look right. Since we\'re about to sunset Foundation 5 from a features perspective
column12: I\'m going to close this out. For v6 we\'ve merged split buttons into button groups
column13: and used less precise positioning to make the component more flexible."'

column10: b'b" I debugged it and see it now. First
column11: your call to... ...is causing **another** ::init() which forces a call to ::reflow() which triggers a \'change\' event. You can get around this by setting \'initial\' like this: url  This cuts (++i) down to 2 from 4. Now what is causing the 2?  The answer (unsure if I should fix it or not because we need to know about window resizing) ::init() forces a call to ::reflow() which triggers a \'change\' event.  Then
column12: triggers a \'\' which triggers another ::reflow() which triggers another \'change\' event."'

column10: b'b" Thanks all for what you did
column11: I\'ve got my answer.And I noticed that the window size change can trigger the slider event
column12: is that reasonable?"'

column10: b"b' Yup.  And changing a device from landscape to portrait will also trigger it.'"
b"b' Can we close this issue?'"
b"b' Yeah
column11: thanks a lot.'"

column11: I have looked into checkbox problems in Firefox
column12: and don\\\'t have a fix quite yet. The code basically looks for the nearest parent div with a class of row
column13: and then searches for all inputs of type checkbox and inverts their checked attribute. I am suspicious that the way Firefox handles the checked attribute is different. My hypothesis is that some browsers use the simple "checked" attribute
column14: and some use "checked=checked"
column15: and firefox handles those cases differently then other browsers
column16: but havn\\\'t verified the true cause yet. I\\\'ll update here when I have a fix.  Also I am looking in to the  error. No updates on that one yet either
column17: but there should be soon. Erik\''

column10: b"b' Addendum Apps should leave users with a  successful outcome. The design of an app should lead users through the process and options.  So far a great stride was in making the CREATE PATH TO FOLDER the first allowable user interaction -However  as you can see by my notes above  . . .  a bit more work needs to be done on YETI LAUNCH design and interaction so people have no questions.'"
b'b" @blynnc Thanks for sharing your experience.  I think that the reason the background color isn\'t changing is that it doesn\'t know what $black is. I checked
column11: and there is a line a few lines above the background color
column12: that defines the black color. I tested your situation with the $black also uncommented
column13: and it worked. Could you try that and let me know if it solves your problem? The other issue is that Yeti Launch isn\'t reporting the scss error of an undefined variable (or anything else). This can give the impression that scss succeeded in compiling
column14: when in reality there is an error. We have patched this so that Yeti Launch does report scss errors . The patch is in QA right now
column15: apologies for any trouble that has caused you. We will be releasing it as soon as we possibly can. Expect it no later than early next week. I can allow underscores in project names for future versions of yeti launch. We limited all special characters
column16: and didn\'t consider that underscores might be something people want. Thanks for bringing that to our attention. Lastly
column17: I agree 100%. The app should leave users with a successful outcome
column18: and guide them through the whole process. We definitely have had some bumps during launch week
column19: but are firmly committed to seeing them through. We want this to be an incredible resource for front end developers
column20: and these small usability issues certainly hamstring its potential. Feedback like yours is helpful for us to bring a great product to the table
column21: so thank you for sharing. Screenshot of the setting to also uncomment: url  Have a happy thanksgiving! Erik"'

Underscores _ are a rather common  special character used in naming  files and folder names. At least I\'ve always used them or a combination of  underscores and dashes. underscore_item-1.jpg or  folder_system-2 Thanks again. Happy Thanksgiving to entire crew. P.S. I think I saw a YETI the other day. It was dark and I was driving home from my workout session. A dark shape (not a coyote) sort of like  a hunched over human but not quite ran across the street. All I got was the impression of a dark shape -seemed like it might have been a YETI  ;  ). If it wasn\'t a YETI than it might have been a bear."'

column10: b'b" So
column11: if the viewport is smaller than the minimum breakpoint
column12: the calc function kicks out before it starts
column13: thus the failure to resize the container appropriately. I\'ll take a look at remedying that in the new year
column14: plus some other minor optimizations for sticky."'

b'b" Hi
column11: to stop the first megellan menu item being rendered active before it\'s reached an anchor point you can modify the function _updateActive(). The variable curIdx holds the array position of the item the active class will be added to and if winPos < [0] is true it means that an anchor has not been reached so by changing curIdx from 0 to undefined in the if else statement it will fix the issue. This will also let you scroll back up over the first anchor point and there will be no active classes. Modifying this variable doesn\'t look like it will affect the rest of the code at all but I haven\'t run any proper tests. I have also submitted a pull request. "'

column10: b'b" [Global Styles] Disabled buttons\' colors are not accessible"'

column14: and #7103._ Accessibility Question: Does it matter that an element is accessible if it cannot be interacted with? (Perhaps @Owlbertz might weigh in.) '"

column10: b"b' I think there are two things to consider: people that are (partly) not able to see colors and screen readers (for people that cannot see at all). For the first case
column11: the disabled style is not accessible for sure because of the pretty low (its 3.01 to 1
column12: needs to be at least 4.5 to 1). I am not sure if there are any hard requirements for the style of disabled states
column13: maybe the cursor could change to the disabled state when hovering? Regarding screen readers everything should be fine as long as there is the disabled attribute. This is currently not set
column14: but I think this rather than the class should indicate the disabled state.'"

column10: b"b' @gakimball regarding #7379: the difference between and should be
column11: that not all elements support according to HTML standard and that actually disables the element
column12: while just indicates a disabled UI component to AT. This means
column13: would go with the attribute
column14: and would need to use or  . I feel like we should include all three ways in the CSS selector

column10: b'b\' I am working on a Portfolio widget with the modes "Modal"
column11:
Card" and "Orbit" based on Foundation 6 for inclusion in user webpages created with Hubzilla, a decentralized and privacy respecting publishing solution. The idea is to allow an automated and hands-off portfolio for painters, photographers and other artists, with flexibility for web developers.  I am nearly done, so this will be included in Hubzilla 2.6. However, I am having some trouble with Orbit height.  Users upload their images to one or more albums with WebDAV using something like the FolderSync app on their phone or tablet, a file manager with such support or command line rsync, or simply manually uploading through the web interface. Albums are access controlled, the Internet, some group, my friends, only me and so on. Upon upload, Hubzilla will automatically create four sizes size 0 or Original size available from the file system, while size 1 large , size 2 medium and size 3 small are in the database. Widgets are created using PHP and Smarty3 templates, then included into blocks and regions in layouts using a page description language called Comanche, and then finally the layout is attached to user\\\'s webpage.  The Portfolio widget takes three parameters album, album title and mode, either Modal, Card or Orbit. Since I cannot know how each instance of the Portrait widget is used at different Hubzilla sites, I am going by the assumption images can have any width or height, and these will be square, landscape or portrait, probably all three in the same album. Modal is done, the widget fetches images from the chosen album, displays them as thumbnails and when you click them you get fullscreen mode this was very easy with Foundation 6 thanks. Card is nearly done, for some reason card-border and card-shadow seems to be missing any help on that would be appreciated. Otherwise, quite easy.  Orbit has been the most difficult to get right, and I have not done the buttons at the bottom yet, need some more Smarty3 foo there. The W3 validator also complains about buttons inside UL and the figcaption, but it works. I seem to have a handle on square and landscape images needs some more grid understanding on my part to tweak just right. However, portrait images mixed with square and landscape images are not handled well at the moment. An example is available at url  . May be #nsfw in your country (one arty 3D drawing of nude pregnant woman praying made with Makehuman and POV-Ray).  In the example page, all images are Hubzilla size 3, i.e. the small version. There is one tall portrait image, and Orbit seems to be confused about the height of the entire slideshow, taking the tallest image as its reference (?). The result is the other images are distorted and scaled into a blur.  What I would like to happen, is to be able to set a height for the slideshow using the Foundation grid, have the image height not be higher than the slideshow, and preferably scaled correctly. Is this possible?\''

column10: b"b' F6 Abide hidden input fields preventing proper error message display'"
b'b" Hi guys
column11: It\'s taken me a while to figure out what is going on  problem is that any form I have with hidden input fields is preventing the .form-error fields from showing when the form is submitted and invalid.  I recognise that I can use the data-abide-ignore feature but as I am working on a Wordpress template I cannot manipulate the output of the nonce or the _wp_http_referer fields to add the attribute. My first thought was to detect these via jQuery and to retrospectively add the data-abide-ignore attribute to these fields but it hasn\'t made any difference to the outcome.  Is it that Abide needs to be re-initialised?  If so how does one do this?  If  help :-) Cheers
column12: Will"'

column10: b"b' Outstanding!  Thanks for the quick response. :-)'"
b'b" I\'m experiencing this exact issue when Rails adds hidden inputs. I know the workaround works
column11: but I think this issue ought to be re-evaluated.  The problem ultimately occurs in because it simply traverses up to the hidden field\'s parent to find _all_ its elements. This parent element may contain any number of invalid fields with visible form-errors that will then be hidden because the hidden field is valid. Because this is the case
column12: I think a much cleaner hack is to simply override this method to ignore hidden fields: A few questionsWhy would a hidden input be validated (by default) at all? Would it be reasonable to add a attribute-level option for ignoring fields by jQuery selector or simply one for ignoring hidden fields?Why are inputs not evaluated for at the time of validation so that a reflow wouldn\'t be necessary?s be tightly bound to inputs to prevent this kind cross-contamination of  states?"'

column10: b'b" This issue ought to be re-opened. If hidden inputs break abide then I\'d call that a major
column11: show-stopping bug. IMO
column12: hidden inputs should never be validated. It\'s not possible for users to modify their values (without js magic
column13: and if you\'ve implemented js magic to change hidden input values
column14: then you could implement js magic to validate them or the visible controls as well). Also
column15: I agree that should be evaluated at time of validation rather than [upon init]url  A new option could be introduced but since I think that 99.99% of people would want hidden inputs ignored
column16: it\'s worth the foregoing such an option for simplicity\'s sake."'

column10: b"b' Furthermore
column11: it appears that the [HTML5 spec indicates]url  that fields [should not be validated]url '"

column10: b"b' I agree this should be reopened.  Hidden inputs should be ignored by Abide.  '"

column10: b'b\' As to feedback
column11: I did read "how to upgrade" before upgrading my existing project. I jumped to that part of the document to carefully read those parts and execute what they were saying
column12: then returned to the top. Normally
column13: from my understanding
column14: bower update" would be the way to do the update, but instead you seemed to be indicating that npm install foundation-sites@beta would do the update. So I tried it, but it did not update my code. I decided to just merge in the changes by comparing the Foundation-sites equivalent folder in 6.2.0 RC1 and my zurb template equivalent folder. I noted that the  and  were not part of the zurb template foundation-sites structure, so I didn\\\'t know what to do with them, leaving them in place in the foundation-sites origin. I tried foundation watch  after the merge, and I don\\\'t recall what errors caused me to think I needed to move those two files up to the zurb template root (renaming the old ), but I did, and that is when I got the parse errors indicated. So I\\\'ve since moved the 2 files back into the foundation-sites folder and reverted to the original  associated with zurb template. This seems to have gotten me further down the road, but still new problems. Upon executing foundation watch, I now get errors indicating that rem-calc is being passed "small 20px" which is not a number, but I can assure you that I\\\'m not passing that anywhere in my code, only  alphas\\xe2\\x80\\xa6. Resulting in the  is not being compiled. Please enlighten me if you know what would be causing this. My searches have turned up nothing. I\\\'m also getting notice further down in the terminal output: [BABEL] Note: The code generator has deoptimized the styling of \\xe2\\x80\\xa6\\xe2\\x80\\xa6." as it exceeds the max of "100KB". The end result is that appears to be watching and serving files from "dist" but my zurb template based page is no longer styled or js\\\'d. Go figure, this is my result of "updating" to 6.2rc. As I said. These are the types of frustrations that have haunted me throughout my "modern tooling" with Foundation 6.x. Regarding your general comments about the state of modern tooling, I\\\'m not the only one questioning whether the current node package dependency-crazy tooling (especially on Windows it would seem) is a step forward due to the level of chaos inherent in it. It does make me consider strongly going back to a standard compiler such as pre-pros even though I like others, want to stay on the leading edge\\xe2\\x80\\xa6.and yes, I understand that pre-pros has nowhere near the utility (like uncss, etc.), assuming that the utility is actually functional instead of just a perpetual headache. Regarding your comment about your "documentation tends to skew more towards advanced developers," I think it always pays to remember that because you\\\'re paid to work on the tooling  and the framework all day long, those who are trying to use it are not, which can cause you to lose site of the forest. Developers like myself are resorting to a framework as a means to an end, and we are de facto generalists because we have such broad roles and responsibilities that there is no way that we can be as deep into the tooling and the technologies behind it as you are. So you do indeed tend to make too many assumptions in conveying many of the basics because you are "soaking in it
column15: whereas people like myself are a single  covering an entire 10 person team\\\'s responsibilities
column16: on 5 different sites. It is not as if we wouldn\\\'t prefer to stop the world and go deeper than our jobs allow us to
column17: but sheer constraint of unrealistic job scope prevents that. So I would caution you not to be condescending when thinking about your users. With all of the above said
column18: can you help me to remain on 6.2rc and get past these compiling errors
column19: or should I revert so that I can get back to work? Please respond ASAP.\''

column10: b'b" To address each of your issues:1. Our Sass templates manage the Foundation dependency through Bower
column11: not npm. So installing a new version of Foundation through npm won\'t do anything.2. As for the Sass error
column12: I think it\'s cropping up anywhere you use with if I had to guess. Could you post a full stack trace of the error?3. For the Babel error
column13: try placing _above_ in your Gulpfile. The upgrade guide will be updated to reflect this. Regarding the documentation
column14: you\'re absolutely right. We\'ve been reviewing our messaging and positioning for the framework
column15: and one thing coming out of that is that we\'re losing sight of the basics. You can even see this on the [landing page]url  for Sites\\xe2\\x80\\x94it talks a lot about new features
column16: or how our framework is different from others
column17: or advanced stuff
column18: but not enough time talking about _what a framework actually is_. So know that we\'re aware of the knowledge gap that exists in our messaging and our documentation
column19: and we aim to address it. Lastly
column20: I\'ll say thank you so much for trying out the release candidate. This is something we\'ve never done before\\xe2\\x80\\x94we tend to just release minor versions with no build-up. We\'re trying to put new stuff out in the open sooner so we can identify issues ahead of the time. It means a lot that you\'d take the time to break down the problems you\'ve been having
column21: so thank you for that."'

column10: b'b" You are preaching to the choirs. I\'m not defending Prototype at all
column11: I absolutely loathe it. However
column12: it is so deeply rooted in Magento 1\'s front-end that removing it would require rewriting most of its core. column10: b"b' [Reveal] steals focus and key events'"
b'b" First
column11: thank you for Foundation
column12: I appreciate all the work that you\'ve put into this! I am using a Reveal modal with the intent to show search results. If you are familiar with search in iOS\' calendar then you\'ll have a good sense of the goal. If you that doesn\'t clarify then it\'s sufficient to know that the goal is to open a modal while retaining focus in a text field. Surprisingly
column13: opening the reveal modal removes the focus from a text input. I\'ve tried to handle the \'\' event to take focus back
column14: but that results in a warning \'Component not defined!\' inside of  and causes key events to be lost. Specifically the text input appears to have focus
column15: but all typing is lost. I understand that taking focus is intended for screen readers
column16: however
column17: I\'m wondering if this could be made optional behaviour
column18: or if somehow both goals could be achieved. To demonstrate see url  and start typing in the text field. The first key press causes a modal to appear after which the text input appears to have the focus
column19: but all key events are lost."'

column10: b"b' It seems in  on line 339 in the call to is what stops the key events propagating out of the reveal. Is stopping key events strictly necessary?'"
b"b' Yes
column11: this behavior is intended to properly support screen readers and keyboard access in general. But I guess that your use case is somewhat special and was therefore not considered during design.  I will have a look at this one. I guess there should be a way using the events to move the focus back as you tried it or just a property to disable focus management. In either way you would have to track the tab-event by yourself and shift the focus into the modal (if this is a thing for you).'"

column10: b"b' Check out #8453. I also made some JS for in [this pen]url '"
b'b" I added the changes from #8453 into my project and it works
column11: thank you. I had assumed
column12: like you
column13: we\'d need to add a property to disable focus management
column14: but with the change above the additional property is unnecessary for my use case. As reassigning focus on the event hook is sufficient."'

column10: b'b" I\'ve upgraded to 6.2.3 from my previously patched version that resolved the issue above and am seeing the issue described above again. That is
column11: opening a reveal causes focus to be lost on input\'s that exist outside of the reveal. I\'ve forked the original pen from this issue to reproduce the problem
column12: url  This pen changes to the official foundation version and adds in motion-ui animation on reveal open. When the reveal is animated open changing focus on the open event no longer works because the open event is called after the animation completes. The callback therefore occurs outside of the click event stack and the browser then ignores the javascript focus request. I think we could fix this in one of two ways.1. In the Reveal do not set the focus
column13: i.e. starting at :259 on master:  // handle accessibility  this.$element  .attr({    \'aria-hidden\': false
column14: \'tabindex\': -1  })  .focus(); // Remove this call The focus is taken for accessibility reasons. So rather than outright removal
column15: perhaps we add a condition on this behaviour (not ideal)
column16: so that the focus is assigned to a specified element
column17: e.g. data-open-focus.1. Add a before open event for the reveal where we can set the focus before the animation occurs. Which opens a larger design question as I believe there are no other \'before\' events in Foundation. In the meantime I have two potential workarounds
column18: I can patch foundation to remove the focus (accessibility is not important for our user base
column19: yet)
column20: or disable the animation until this is fixed. Thanks."'

column10: b"b' Minor correction. The line number where focus is stolen from the text field is 240 in the afterAnimationFocus() callback
column11: not the regular accessibility handling as I pointed out above.'"

column10: b"b' Hi @josh-h
column11: thank you for the detailed analysis.If you think you can fix this issue
column12: we are always happy to see a pull request!'"

column10: b'b" Interesting. I hadn\'t thought about Reveal being used this way.  But I think the function of a modal inherently steals focus away from the main content. So Reveal probably isn\'t the right component for this use case.  It could be done more simply with and a function to toggle the hide class. What do you think of an approach like this? url  If the results need to be positioned like a modal
column11: you could do that with app-specific styles ( ). But I notice you\'ve actually removed the overlay to make it behave even less like a modal\\xe2\\x80\\x94which again makes me think Reveal is the wrong component.  Can anyone think of an instance where Reveal would need to behave exactly as it does out-of-the-box
column12: except for stealing focus? "'

column10: b'b" I would tend to agree that perhaps reveal isn\'t the right component for this behavior... I\'d be inclined towards a callout
column11: though I\'ve also implemented behavior somewhat like this with dropdowns. My inclination is to close this as a \'wontfix\'.  @josh-h I do want to make sure you found a solution for your usecase though... did you get this working in some form?"'

column10: b'b" Agreed
column11: @kball. I\'ll go ahead and close this. However
column12: @josh-h
column13: please feel free to continue the conversation if you still need help. "'

b'b" This is due to the same thing as url  What\'s going on is a set of sticky intialization code is wrapped in an event handler on the window load.  I\'m not entirely sure why sticky is trying to have some things happen on load... probably because the page may not be done laying out
column11: but the current approach assumes that a sticky is always instantiated before pageload. I think the fix is probably to do the full instantiation immediately
column12: but add a load handler that will recompute things as necessary. Given how much sticky depends on the dimensions of its anchor
column13: it seems like another good candidate for url
column14: however it also depends on the position of the anchor in the page
column15: which I don\'t think data-mutate would catch... any thoughts on how to watch for that @coreysyms?"'

column10: b'b" So a couple things. 1) This and any ajax loaded content being added to sticky or it\'s parent container or anchor container would be a great candidate for data-mutate. The mutate trigger would most likely need to call setSizes() in  as it sits now. 2)For this particular case
column11: the mutate listening elements are removed from the DOM and replaced
column12: (even though it looks the same on the page it\'s different and new) and everything about sticky in this case is removed and replaced. So technically speaking
column13: this is a mutate event
column14: but sticky can\'t / won\'t react to it because it is removed. The only thing that would react to mutate is off-canvas
column15: since all the new DOM elements are loaded into it\'s container. @phifa is correct in trying to (re)initalize any plugin
column16: however... (see issue 3) 3) The real issue is $(window).one() in my opinion
column17: since  is never fired again. Sticky only initializes once. This should be re-written."'

b"b' I concur on using rather than  .  Curious what @andycochran @brettsmason and @JeremyEnglert think about the question on lightness of links inside callouts.'"

b'b\' It would be a pain to have to apply a class to every link inside callouts just to fix their color.  This reminds me of a previous issue: Headers used to have an explicit color. We switched to so that nested components with different  colors wouldn\\\'t need to each declare specific header colors.  But this is more complicated with links. The nature of cascade works against us here. Since we\\\'re applying a specific color to links
column11: a component which needs a different link color must have a rule with more specificity for its links. And this new rule will cascade to all components within. So
column12: if a further-nested component needs a different link color
column13: it must have a rule with _even more_ specificity for its links. And links continue to require greater and greater specificity for each level of nesting.  I\\\'d suggest that we support setting a link color for callouts and note in the docs that "because of the nature of cascade
column14: callouts with nested components require app-specific styling to reset those components\\\' link colors." \''

column10: b'b" What about using explicit descendant selectors? For example
column11: link colors could be defined for particular descendants in a callout.  This way
column12: nested component won\'t be effected. No classes necessary. "'

column10: b"b' @andycochran This is a well-know problem in BEM
column11: resolved by the [Scope classes]url  With the solution you propose
column12: links that are direct childs are affected
column13: but links inside a grid (or any other invisible component or utility) are not. Explicit descendant selectors does not resolve the problem
column14: it moves it. Also
column15: it keep a specificity of and does not resolve:'"

column10: b'b" Good point
column11: @ncoden. I\'d like to withdraw my off-the-cuff descendant selectors suggestion.  I suppose we have to make a choice
column12: decide which is a bigger problem:  **Option A:** _Callout Link Classes_Pro: Nested components aren\'t effected by callout link colors. Con: Callout links require a specific class to get the appropriate color.  **Option B:** _No Link Classes_Pro: All links in callouts are automatically colored appropriately. Con: Nested components require app-specific styles.  How common is it to include nested components in callouts? I\'ve never needed to. But I very often have links in my callouts
column13: and I\'d hate to have to apply classes to those. If the primary function of callouts is an alert or block of
column14: I\'d like to avoid over-engineering a solution that enables callouts to be used for [any unspecified purpose]. "'

column10: b"b' **Option C**: _Callout Scope Modifier_ (  or more strictly ) _Callout Link Classes_ (  or more stricly  )  \\xe2\\x9c\\x93 Pro: Nested components can being not affected by callout link colors.  \\xe2\\x9c\\x93 Pro: All links in callouts can be automatically colored appropriately.   _How to make the best Sass approach ever ? Take BEM
column11: SMACSS
column12: ITCSS and mix everything !_  Disclaimer: I seen _scopes_ and _modifiers_ before
column13: but never _scoping modifiers_. Use it at your own risks.'"

column10: b'b" Can we update this PR to work with the new function and @ncoden\'s suggestions? "'
b"b' Beyond using the BEM *element* to apply properties precisely
column11: my suggestions introduce a new concept to keep the component simple : scoping modifiers.  With **scoping modifier** for a simple use case: (or  )  With callout **link elements** to apply properties precisely: (or  )  @kball I would have your opinion on this.'"

column10: b'b\' I think this concept of a scoping modifier is a potentially a really nice way to walk the balance between control and  of use.  For folks doing simple things
column11: they can use the scoping modifier and it will "just work" (TM).  For folks who want more control
column12: are building complex nesting things
column13: or big apps
column14: they can apply the link element classes.  I dig it.  Can we look at some other cases where we might use this concept and see if there are any gotchas lurking?  \''

column10: b'b" @kball Almost everywhere I yelled against properties applied from the parent. We don\'t have a high specificity because it\'s cool to have unmaintainable stuff
column11: but because it permits to have easily usable components (as long as you have a basic usage).  Everywhere there is properties applied from a parent (grid
column12: menu
column13: dropdown
column14: top-bar...)
column15: we could switch to a set of modifiers + a scoping modifier."'

column10: b'b" Sorry
column11: i somewhat dropped out of that ! But i believe you resolve the issue to everybodies satisfaction. \\xf0\\x9f\\x91\\x8d Please don\'t forget the text color in Callouts! The reason i stumbled upon this problem is
column12: that we use Callouts in combination with
column13: and for messages to the user. In addition we also set to to stay within our defined color palette and not genereate various shades of a color.  But with a dark red for the usual blackish is very hard to read
column14: if at all! And which should resolve that problem wasn\'t used at all. The same goes for the link color in Callouts. To make things more complicated
column15: we offer a SaaS application which is customized via for our customers. Therefore we rely on the fact
column16: that the colors configured there result in a  CSS file without black text on black backgrounds for example."'

b'b" Don\'t listen to touchend events on dropdown element leafs."'

b'b" Don\'t listen to  touchend  events on dropdown element leafs. This seems to be missing and was causing issues on touch devices.  Steps to reproduce using Foundation Sites 6.3.0:  * Use the example dropdown menu code from url * Add a real link to on submenu Item 1A (i.e. url * On iPad (or any touch device) click the link for Item 1A  Result: On the iPad the site doesn\'t navigate to the link added
column11: while on desktop it does.  Expect: Both touch and desktop to navigate to the link added.  fix #9484"'

column10: b"b' Sorry for  the PR. Seems that Travis CI is failing due connectivity issues :( On my end all tests are passing.'"
b'b" This change doesn\'t really make sense to me if I\'m understanding correctly
column11: called without any parameters hides the entire dropdown
column12: while if you pass in an $elem it expects that $elem to contain a submenu
column13: and it will close that submenu specifically... here we\'re in a case explicitly without a submenu
column14: so I\'m not clear why we want to pass in $elem.  Can you explain a little more why this addresses #9484?"'

column10: b'b" I followed similar approach as on the  and  where they are sending also the same $(this) to the hide method.  Reading your comment
column11: you\'re probably right that maybe that\'s not correct and something like  parentsUntil  should be used instead.  The reason of adding it was that during debugging it looked like the touchend event behaves differently from the click
column12: and the link navigation refuses to happen when the  this.$element  is hidden.  I\'ll refactor it to use a  parentsUntil  to see if it makes a difference and debug it further to find out the exact reason why it happens."'

column10: b'b" After some debugging
column11: the delay on touch devices between the  click  (which at least on iOS is who internally does the link navigation) and  touchend  events was preventing the link navigation.  It seems that browser security policies don\'t allow link navigation on hidden elements
column12: so the  touchend  event is hiding the menu
column13: before the internal click for the navigation is happening.  I opted for removing the  touchend  and let the  click  to handle the hiding. This way
column14: even though there will be a 300ms delay for hiding the menu in case there is no link
column15: any actual link or action works as expected."'

column10: b'b" A few thoughts:  At first glance
column11: a prototype with classes for adjusting spacing seems like too fine-grained a prototype
column12: but I also haven\'t done any web-based prototyping in a while. Foundation has sensible defaults for spacing between components
column13: so I feel like if you\'re at the point of needing to fine-tune spacing
column14: you\'re past prototyping and into implementing a design. (I\'m sure someone could give an example of where these classes would be useful in the  phase
column15: however!) Including certain features only in the CSS version might prove too confusing. The distinction between the Sass and CSS flavors of Foundation is not always telegraphed super clear in the documentation
column16: but one thing is constant: the Sass version has *more* features than the CSS version. Would things get too weird if the Sass version had some exclusive features
column17: and the CSS version had some exclusive features also?  In general
column18: I don\'t consider it a good practice. I think there are useful arguments to be made in favor of using layout classes like and such in production
column19: but I can\'t think of any for numeric spacing classes. The prototyping angle I almost get
column20: but I\'d like to hear an example of where such fine-tuning was necessary to sell an HTML prototype.  If there was enough demand
column21: perhaps a contributor could produce a small library for people to install separately."'

column10: b'b"  I\'m liking the sound of this the most.  To give a little more about my personal experience
column11: we\'ve had devs help with scaffolding as we wrap visuals and interactions with client projects. The designers then hopped into styling and tightening up scaffolds. What ended up happening was a decent amount of refactoring and organization in the different files. With some more helper classes
column12: it may have helped with the transition from scaffolds to designers. Not sure if anyone else has had these experiences. Would be cool if would automagically warn and remove  if we moved forward with it.   "'

b'b" #### To reproduce:  1. Add classes to a button element e.g. 2. Hover over button with the mouse  Or  1. Add classes to a button element and the attribute e.g. 2. Hover over button with the mouse  #### Expected:  Button should not change in style.  The hover effect suggests an action can be taken.  The button should be displayed in the style
column11: even though disabled
column12: to differentiate it from a standard button which is disabled  #### Happened:  __In v6.3.0__  When the button is hovered over with the mouse
column13: the button changes to have the background colour with the text colour set to the best visibility against the new background (with inherited).  __In v6.3.1__ Button background colour is set to and the text colour is set to the best visibility against the new background (with inherited) and doesn\'t change on hover (so a disabled button is visually the same as a disabled button)  #### :  [Foundation Docs v6.3.0 hollow button disabled example]url  [JSFiddle v6.3.0]url  [JSFiddle v6.3.1]url #### Possibly related: #9021  #9022"'

b'b" @mrYakamoto @kball @andycochran Hello. Sorry for the wait ;)  So
column11: it seems there is a problem with what you\'re expecting.  For now
column12: we have: must be aligned (negative marging on child to counter the parent padding) must be centered (auto margin) So: is centered instead of being aligned.  You want to make the 3rd row with have negative margins too
column13: but it does not have anything to do with
column14: this is a behavior you expect from any nested row.  Despite of the name (let\'s say we use instead of  )
column15: the problem is we\'re f*** by specificity (again
column16: huh ?). Adding an other modifier do the job for this particular situations
column17: but will create more problems for tons of other situations.  So
column18: for now
column19: I only have a bad solution: Ensure both and is aligned (negative margins). This increase the specificity
column20: complexify the behavior
column21: this is nothing but a hack for a badly declared
column22: but... this is what any API base with an uncontrolled specificity will always leads to. And it\'s in these cases we understand the best how much an architecture that lead to nothing but bad solutions is broken.  Let me know what you think about it."'

b"b' PostCSS with Sass Integration?'"
b"b' Carrying on the conversation from url Proposal for Foundation to migrate to PostCSS.  Thread theme music is url '"
b"b' Nice Music!'"
b'b" ## Pros:  All the power of JS instead of a subset of misc functions (for instance
column11: Sass will never have  \\xe2\\x80\\x94which is really handy for working with ratios). Works with every CSS preprocessor AND vanilla CSS
column12: so we\'re no longer ostracizing  users. Super fast.  ## Cons  Docs aren\'t perfect. We could help with that though. It\'s a huge undertaking. The syntactic sugar libs (e.g. nesting
column13: variables
column14: etc.) for it are buggy\\xe2\\x80\\x94especially when you start to combine them
column15: especially when layering a real preprocessor in.  I\'ve found PostCSS is perfect for making libs. Preprocessors are perfect for syntactic sugar.  Foundation is a lib."'

column10: b'b" Another interesting thing I was thinking about postcss for was related to Container Queries.  We did some experiments with container queries using url  that are REALLY COOL! However the prolyfill doesn\'t work well with scss which would make it hard to integrate container queries into the framework itself... UNLESS we move to postcss and set up our own handling of it... which would then enable us to really adopt container queries at a structural level if we wanted to. :D"'

b'b" I don\'t see how PostCSS (compiles to valid CSS) has anything to do with a polyfill (requires JS at runtime).  I think element queries are amazing and url  has been trying to get the W3C to pay attention to his [spec]url  for it for a while...  I\'m all about progressive enhancement but almost everything on clearnet relies on JS
column11: so wouldn\'t be opposed to it.  Anyway
column12: again
column13: it\'s not related to PostCSS so should probably be a new issue."'

column10: b"b' The JS polyfill is the runtime; the way to specify the  queries use some extensions on CSS that caused SCSS preprocessors to barf when I was playing with them
column11: which makes it hard to use in a systematic way within the framework. Was thinking that PostCSS might give us a way to work around that.'"

column10: b'b" Ah
column11: weird. I\'m not sure I\'d break SCSS for people so I could use element queries though. Personally
column12: I use Sass for sugar and some polyfill acting weird would upset me. That said
column13: I\'m sure we could dev a PostCSS prolyfill that would work well with Sass."'

column10: b"b' I like PostCSS; they have modules to process some things SCSS
column11: people use it anyway for Autoprefixer
column12: & other PostCSS modules are handy.'"

column10: b"b' Just for reference
column11: node-sass can be combined with post-css nicely.  EG:  '"

column10: b'b" If you guys do PostCSS
column11: I can port my ratio method from postcss-ant to Foundation
column12: allowing for these types of layouts: url Then people could do something like: url Designers want to use ratios
column13: but keep having to work with simple fractions. It\'d be something unique to your grid."'

column10: b'b" Looks great @corysimmons; I\'d love me some Golden Ratio!  But I\'d imagine backwards compatibility + more complex core codebase would be an issue; could a ratio plugin be better?"'
b'b" Oops
column11: I added what it might look like in Sass while simultaneously promoting PostCSS. Fail.  tbh
column12: I\'m not sure how to approach it in Sass off the top of my head. It can _probably_ be done. I suppose some crazy loop stuff would work
column13: but taking gutters into account and such
column14: bleh... it just always seems Sisyphusy.  It just bothers me to think of weird loop hacks to workaround Sass\' shortcomings... Why? Because it\'s popular. So is PostCSS
column15: and it has all the power of JS.   A completely separate reason for PostCSS would be that there are more devs moving to CSS-in-JS than there are devs hanging out around the Sass ecosystem.  If you write the JS in PostCSS
column16: people can use it in whatever frontend they want like. They can also just import what they need instead of the whole framework.   You can reuse a lot of the same JS to generate custom dist stylesheets.  So far as people who don\'t use CSS-in-JS
column17: we could _still_ rely on the same parts of a single codebase
column18: just a different API (that would be consistent throughout every preprocessor and vanilla CSS):    Yes
column19: it\'d be challenging.  Yes
column20: it\'s possible and I think it\'s the best solution as opposed to sticking with weaker tech for popularity that _will_ fade as more-and-more frontend devs get CTO positions and make CSS-in-JS mandatory.  tbh
column21: I\'m not sure when you\'re planning to release your next version so it might not make sense to table-flip if it\'s just around the corner
column22: but I think these arguments are valid for the future

b"b' Equalizer elements wrong height until page is resized'"

b"b' Updated to 6.3.1 from 6.2.4 but I am still seeing equalizer elements appearing too high on initial load of page. They contract to the correct height when the page is resized. This issue seems to be only happening on webkit browsers. Safari on mac is affected but not Chrome & Firefox.  Also
column11: there are no images in the Equalizer panels
column12: just a header and paragraph.  #### How to reproduce this bug:  Install 6.3.1. Add 3 columns with header and paragraph content and equalizer markup. Load page in Safari on mac. Then resize page to see correct rendering.  #### What should happen:  Equalizer elements should be equal height.  #### What happened instead:  Equalizer elements are equal height but almost double the required space with no content in the bottom half. On any page resize the elements reduce in size to appear correctly.  #### Browser(s) and Device(s) tested on:  Mac OS 10.12.4 Safari (10.1) Issue not present in Firefox & Chrome on same mac
column13: but is visible in Espresso (Webkit also)  Can anyone help with this? The issue seems to be going on for some time as I have seen this happening since F5
column14: so someone must have come across it? '"

column11: from my tests I have isolated the issue to the inclusion of webfonts. Once I removed the web fonts from my test it works as expected. But when the content is using webfonts the Equalizer issue is present. I have attached screenshots of the issue I am referring to.  And here are my test links:  [Test with Web Fonts]url  (displays issue)  [Test without Web Fonts]url  (no issue)  ![screen shot 2017-05-04 at 11 46 32]url  ![screen shot 2017-05-04 at 11 49 42]url  '"

column10: b'b" I\'m not using a Mac so I can\'t really help you understand why it is rendered like this on Safari (probably related to the way fonts are loaded by Safari) but that makes me think of what we call [FOUT (**F**lash **O**f **U**nstyled **C**ontent)]url Back to your issue: this is not Foundation responsibility to handle custom fonts loading but you can try to use something like [Font Face Observer]url  to wait for fonts to load and then initialize Foundation: (I have never used this library so read the documentation if my example doesn\'t work)  If you want to know more about the way custom fonts are loaded by browsers and FOUT
column11: you may want read this blog post: url I hope it helps!"'

column11: @JeremyEnglert  yes most non-cssgrid fallbacks can\'t quarantine legacy fallback code from modern browsers. On a recent project using cssgrid I used an \'unframework\' mixin to reset within the supports(display:grid) query and that approach isn\'t too bloaty IMO.  In the grand picture
column12: I am super keen to be using cssgrid more _today_
column13: but increasingly I\'ve come to ponder how much of a framework is actually needed to implement cssgrid part of it\'s appeal is to make frameworks redundant. But what I have wanted the most out of a framework is a way to manage fallbacks for cssgrid.  (Hence the attraction of this discussion).  CSS Grid should be encouraging us to do far more interesting things than the narrow range of 12 col  modular layouts we\'ve gotten used to.  The simplest legacy encompassing solution is to support IE via a single column (mobile-esque) layout
column14: and go to town for with cssgrid for modern browsers.  Sooner or later that is what we will ALL be doing.  But if we still have to do better for IE todau
column15: then managing fallbacks more generously seems to me to be a good use case for grid frameworks in 2017."'

column10: b'b" New version should use the most advanced possible HTML features available.
column11: so that\'s CSS grid. Given that decision I don\'t believe there should be a fallback. Is there a fallback that covers the same features 100%? Probably not. So in a new version I wouldn\'t consider fallbacks at all. Flex is a decent layout system but it is not a grid fallback no matter how you bend it. Also
column12: on the topic of IE support I\'d discountinue it. It\'s unfortunately a browser that lost all support even within MS so if enterprise wants to stick with it in their internal environments for whatever reason they should find their own ways. Modern websites are going forward. It\'s a bit different with custom web apps when you have a client on the other side and if you have a client that demands IE support you need to communicate to them what that means in terms of development so all in all supporting old tech costs more. These decisions are pretty much made case by case and that\'s why you should not base you next CSS framework on it. Otoh
column13: someone already mentioned that CSS grid makes the case for custom frameworks less viable because it solves the grid problem by itself. This is an interesting POV and one that I would seriously consider. Meaning
column14: with the introduction of CSS grid
column15: one does not need a grid component in their CSS framework. Meaning
column16: CSS grid marginalizes CSS frameworks to more of a styling utilities and less of a layout systems. Best"'

column10: b"b' We will only drop IE9 (and 10) support.'"

b'b" Let me chime in after another few months have passed. We have decided for new projects to drop support even for IE11 because it just lacks some crucial features (or they work differently than they do in modern browsers). We will display a prompt (somewhat like a cookie prompt) that the site hasn\'t been optimized for IE and that the visitor is getting worse experience (we will not block them completely though).  Now
column11: that being said and having worked with CSS Grid a couple of times in the past months
column12: I still find it somewhat lacking when compared to Foundation\'s XY grid. What I mean: the CSS subgrid hasn\'t been implemented yet (see url  so when you hit a more complex example you will suffer. Also
column13: I find it harder to come up with responsive grid because it is a lot more work to do than just placing small-x
column14: medium-y
column15: etc classes on divs (the process becomes more verbose with CSS grid).  I think personally I will weigh project by project when to use CSS Grid and when use Foundation\'s XY grid.  I still remain convinced that we do not need any new version of grid in the next version of framework
column16: for more complex layout I will be using XY grid and for simpler layouts CSS Grid (hoping CSS subgrid to hit soon
column17: ie in a couple of months)."'

b"b' Drilldown method to show any menu'"

b'b" This PR adds the new method to the drilldown component for opening any (sub)menu in it **without** clicking through every menu on the way to it.  I usually like the drilldown menu because it\'s a nice and intuitive navi which I often use in the off-canvas. But it has a huge downside: there\'s currently no method to jump into a specific submenu without clicking through several submenus.  I\'ve added a visual test in this PR that shows the difference between the current and the new  . You\'ll see what I mean when you check the \'Use current show\' checkbox and click the buttons C
column11: B
column12: X (in this order) and then use the back links. url The new method is probably a great feature for everyone who needs to e.g. auto open the current page in the drilldown if using it as page navi.  @IamManchanda @kball @brettsmason what do you think? "'

column10: b'b" This is not awesome... this is super awesome !!! Hats off  Its like deeplinking came into drilldown\'s :wink: cc @kball for !"'

b'b" @IamManchanda many thanks for your kindly words! I\'m glad to hear this feature is appreciated \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x83 Apart from your requested change (see my comment above) I\'ve made another slight improvement: The method has now a second param called which will prevent the auto focus of the first link in the target (sub)menu if false. I think this might by helpful in cases where the auto focus is not desired (e.g. if the drilldown is hidden when calling that function). Default remains true. "'

b'b" Testing through the visual test I see a few issues  1. When I click in using the \'showMenu\' option I get some weird focus behavior (the focus ring which is supposed to only show on keyboard nav starts showing on elements within the drilldown. 2. When I keyboard nav around
column11: I seem to occasionally trigger some sort of behavior where the entire drilldown becomes hidden.  Both of these were in Chrome latest (59) on mac"'

column10: b'b\' @kball thanks for your feedback!  1. That\\\'s actually a feature: I\\\'ve added this auto focus so the user can jump right into the drilldown via keyboard after having clicked the trigger (button). Would you prefer no auto focus by default? Currently the auto focus may get disabled by explicitly setting the param to false  2. Would you describe more detailed how to reproduce this? But I think I know what you mean. When I click \\\'Show X\\\'
column11: then above the buttons (lose focus) and then press several times the TAB key the drilldown menus get mixed up. However **this isn\\\'t caused by my changes / PR** because it also happens if you don\\\'t click any button but open "Item A3" the usual way (clicking on it)
column12: then click above the buttons (lose focus) and then press several times the TAB key. I think it\\\'s a general drilldown focus management issue and may be related to this issue url \''

b'b" @isapir there haven\'t been introduced any non backwards compatible changes. What you see on gulping is a **warning** not an **error**.  I\'ve added this to prompt the user to update his settings at an early stage instead of waiting until it has been removed and cause an actual error. Right now the deprecated is still working and gets internally converted into the new  .  I think it\'s not a backwards compatibility issue if you get only a warning."'
b"b' But the thing is we need to improve our settings the way we handle it!'"

Will it be implemented into the current HTML structure like XY Grid or will it be independent from it?  Is there an example of the current thinking?'"

b'b" Please
column11: do not try to shoehorn CSS Grid Layout into Foundation\'s grid system.  url CSS Grid Layout _is_ the framework. It needs no abstraction. Anything you do will make an already complex spec even more complicated and confusing."'

column10: b'b" Don\'t worry
column11: nothing like that!  Our focus is Sass mixins (and functions for progressive fallback)."'

column10: b'b\' This:  And this: would lead me to believe that you _are_ trying to somehow co-opt CSS Grid Layout into an abstracted system.  You do not need to do this.  _Any_ line of code you write will be an unnecessary abstraction and limitation of CSS Grid Layout. If you want to support "progressive enhancement
column11:
then leave CSS Grid Layout out of your codebase and _only_ provide the fallback (no need to do this through either, just make it an optional  ). You cannot provide a CSS Grid Layout framework because it is already a framework.  Cramming CSS Grid Layout into Foundation\\\'s grid system would be like cramming the Bootstrap grid system into Foundationwhile somehow trying to support bothand then providing an extra layer of classes on top. It just doesn\\\'t make sense. The work is already done. Don\\\'t reinvent the wheel.\''

b'b" Hi @murdoch.  So I have a good and a bad news \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x84 The bad news is that the roadmap and objectives changed since October. Foundation 7 will not be built on Foundation 6 (like small improvement and new features)
column11: but the whole architecture have to change. So this will be take far more time than expected.  The good news is that we\'re not doing that for nothing. The whole new framework architecture would make us able to provide far more components
column12: more customizable than ever and most importantly usable in any modern framework like if it was a native component
column13: with all the features offered by the framework.  We are really excited by Foundation 7. There\'s still a lot of things to decide before we ever begin to implement it
column14: but we will make public announcements to keep you informed about the work progress.  Nicolas"'

b"b' Hi I wanted to make it known that the Sticky element in foundation 6.4.3 does not work so well. I refer with precision to the sticky navigation. When you scan the page the elements immediately below the navbar snap and hop.  I tested this issue on Firefox
column11: Chrome and Safari in desktop version and It is visible on your own url  '"

column10: b"b' This seems to come from the navigation bar not having the same height while being sticked or not. When its status change
column11: Foundation will check its height and apply it to the sticky container
column12: so it keep the same height even with its content out of the flow (in  ).  To fix this
column13: we could measure the content height one time to set the container height
column14: and do not change it later when sticked. This could be an option
column15: like  .  @antopossegithub What do you think ?'"

column10: b'b" Yes but it\'s static as a solution!!  It\'s a shame :("'
b"b' Well
column11: the goal of sticky navigation is to allow components to go sticky without affecting the rest of the page
column12: like if the component stayed at the same place.  But at this time
column13: the component is visually _away_. If this component change while being sticky
column14: the page should not be affected.'"

column10: b'b\' Hi @MoarCoding. Thanks for your issue & PR
column11: that\\\'s a nice first contribution \\xf0\\x9f\\x8e\\x89!  I have a few comments to make about it. I hope it will help you to improve yourself in Git and working on Open Source projects. * **Write your commits names and Pull Request title in the "imperative" form.** It must describe "what this  does"
column12: like if the sentence was starting by  . I renamed your PR to * **Use prefixes for commits names and Pull Request title**  like (new feature)
column13: (you repair something)
column14: (documentation)
column15: (you change the code without introducing changes)
column16: (you simply change code formatting)
column17: (units or visual tests) or (for boring day-to-day tasks not touching the actual code). I would recommend you to use them for Foundation
column18: but also your others projects. You can take a look at the [AngularJs Git Commit Message Convention]url  also. * **Describe everything you did and why in your commits and Pull Requests body**. Even if you talked about it in the PR you\\\'re resolving. It\\\'s always helpful later. Explains what you did if the code is not clear enough (but it should be) and for which reasons. Give references (in this case the [W3C Reference about  ]url  would be useful. You should always reference the issue you are closing (like  ). * **Configure Git so it uses your GitHub email address.** See url  This way we can know you are the author of these commits. You can also [sign them]url  if you like. * **Always open a pull request from a dedicated branch.** Like  )
column19: so you branch stay clean and you can provide multiple Pull Requests for various issues.  And finally
column20: here are some helpful ressources for Git: \\xf0\\x9f\\x93\\x9a  * url  * url  * url \''

column11: then say medium and up the mixin should output margin -left and -right set to 0 and calculate the exact width without a subtraction for either gutter.  *Expected outcome:*  ## What happens instead? Small breakpoint is fine. The issue is at each breakpoint the developer cannot remove  from previous even using the variables within the xy-cell().  *Actual outcome:*  ## Possible Solution *I am not sure without making an overly complex mixin.*  ## Your Environment Foundation version(s) used: 6.4.3  ## Checklist (all required): [x] I have read and follow the  document. [x] There are no other issues similar to this one. [x] The issue title is descriptive. [x] The template is correctly filled.  '"

column10: b'b\' Hi @glennphilp
column11: We had a debade recently regarding to how should be used for cells with margin gutters. The issue was that the cell gutter is defined within the cell width so it was not possible to define a cell without defining its gutters. We came to the conclusion that "reseting" (generate zero gutters) and "not generating" was two different things and that does not make sense for margin gutters as it could only be true.  See url Now
column12: is ignored for margin cells and considered as always true. This means that properties will always be generated
column13: with or others values else according to  .  I proposed the following behavior in the discussion:  I think that this new API resolves your issue. However it can bring breaking changes so it will not be released in the upcomming version but in the following one  .  Is it what you expected ?\''

column10: b"b' @ncoden not exactly.  The issue is removing the gutter when a developer wants to target a media query for medium or large. Take the following example

b"b' @DanielRuf When we are locally building Foundation to run tests or start the documentation (for development purposes)
column11: we need peerDependencies to be installed too. Current Yarn (and maybe NPM) versions will not always install them so we need to declare them as both (production) and (development).'"

column10: b'b" Shouldn\'t be sufficient in this case?> NOTE: The production flag has no particular meaning when adding a dependency to a project."'

b"b' I would be devDependencies if we was only delivering dist files (i.e.  ) to copy-paste or import from a CDN. But you can install Foundation from dependencies managers ( ) and in this case we should have our dependencies checked. With we can expect the user to have installed and to be warned otherwise or if their jQuery version is not compatible with ours ( ).'"
b"b' I do not mean jQuery but the dev dependencies.'"
b'b"  I don\'t understand"'
b"b' url '"

b"b' @DanielRuf  * We need and as peerDependencies instead of dependencies because we actually expect the user to install them. We cannot simply remove them because we still need the package managers to check for versions compatibilities and warn the user if they are missing. * We need and as devDependencies too because we use them for  and peerDependencies are not installed (even in development mode url '"
b"b' @DanielRuf So
column11: what do you think ?  See #11294'"

column10: b'b" It made sense to do this for jQuery for all of the reasons you gave
column11: but not for what-input. Most sites that use Foundation don\'t need what-input themselves
column12: but now they all need to add it as a direct dependency of themselves anyway."'

column10: b"b' @josephcsible You are right
column11: is recommended but optional. However
column12: all peerDependencies are optional and the NPM warning message can be safely ignored.  Removing from peerDependencies would prevent us to ensure that the installed version of is compatible with Foundation.'"

column10: b'b" But why can\'t we just use our own version of instead of requiring that whatever uses us have it? Unlike jQuery
column11: there\'s no reason that it has to be the same as ours
column12: right?"'

column10: b'b" @josephcsible We do not require what-input. It is perfectly safe not to install it. Since npm >= 3
column11: npm does not install peerDependencies. This is why we also have these peerDependencies as devDependencies
column12: to ensure we have them installed when running tests.  NPM is not quite suited to the front-end environement. There is optimizations to reduce the number of installed dependencies
column13: but it is nothing compared to the Bower non-deterministic method that forced the user to select a single version of each package.  Peer dependencies are the best way to reproduce this behavior in NPM
column14: and more than that we don\'t force anything to the user. No package is installed by default.  I found a good resume about it in the following article: url  Even if Foundation is not a plugin of
column15: we have the same requirements that resolves: 1. Prevent to install multiple versions of the same package 1. Check the compatibility of the package 3. Allow not to install the package"'

column10: b'b" @ncoden Those two sentences are my concern. I don\'t have any need for what-input
column11: and neither does Foundation
column12: but yarn complains loudly if I don\'t install it
column13: since peer dependencies are considered required."'

column10: b"b' npm throws just a warning in this case that peerDeps are missing (eg adv). Still
column11: what-input is not required to get Foundation Sites working as it progressively enhances Foundation afaik. Do you mean the warning? It is just a warning.'"

column10: b'b\' I guess we should use as describes a requirement (you need this to get it working).  url url It is like a react plugin requiring react to work (peerDep). But it is not really meant as "this is not needed / required".  I think  is often used the wrong way. Let\\\'s test with and see what Yarn and npm say then.  At least what-input. And personally
column11: StackOverflow answers are often not that right / exact (read the docs) ;-)\''

column10: b"b'   is not what it sounds to be. The user cannot controls whether the should be installed. This only means that if npm fails to install the dependency
column11: the installation of your package will continue. It is intended to be used for packages that are only supported on a particular plateform (like  ).'"

column10: b'b\' Hi @zkat \\xf0\\x9f\\x91\\x8b. Could you help us on this. I searched for documentation about how to deal with optional dependencies in web-oriented packages but the only thing I found is from 4 year ago url ### The problem Foundation is a web-oriented package
column11: a framework that provide distribution files to import in the HTML. It relies on (which is definitely a devDependency) and side-effects created by [what-input]url  We do not require  . Foundation works fine without it. We do not import directly. We only need for tests in browser (so it is at least a  ).  ### The question Can be considered as a peerDependency so the user can choose if it is installed and what version to install ? Otherwise
column12: should we care about the "browser environement" of our users and try to reduce the number of dependencies that would be finally required by its project ? Or is it "not our job" and should we not require at all
column13: preventing npm to detect when the user-installed version of is incompatible with Foundation ?  I feels like there is a missing concept
column14: like but not made for plugins (that "require" the main package to be installed by the top user to works) but for packages that can be (or not) installed by the end-user
column15: that we may use directly or indirectly (side-effects in the browser)
column16: but that we can also ignore and still works well.> External dependencies (externalDependencies field in ) are dependencies that are not required to use your package but are used for progressive enhancement. The user can install them separately.\''

column10: b"b'  The developer should do this on his own / manually.  The fields are documented at url  Also see url '"

column12: no actual error: > npm WARN optional-test@1.0.0 requires a peer of what-input@^5.1.1 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself.'"
